The operational design must “fight for information” (JP 3-0) and preserve mission command continuity through redundancy and disciplined communications (JP 6-0).


4. MISSION STATEMENT.

    USINDOPACOM conducts MDJIR (1–15 March 2026) in the Western Pacific to demonstrate and assess multi-domain joint force integration and resilience by (1) denying adversary confidence in achieving a rapid fait accompli through distributed posture and integrated air/maritime maneuver; (2) protecting decision advantage and coalition cohesion through resilient C2 under cyber/EMS/counterspace disruption; and (3) sustaining contested logistics and distributed operations despite intermittent satellite coverage gaps and degraded data systems, in order to provide CJCS/OSD readiness evidence, validated battle drills, and capability gap recommendations in accordance with JP 5-0, JP 3-0, JP 3-52, and CJCSI 3170.01.


5. CONCEPT OF OPERATIONS.

    a. Commander’s intent.

        (1) Purpose. Validate that the joint force can maintain mission command, generate combat power from distributed locations, and sustain operational endurance when space and cyberspace support are degraded and logistics nodes are threatened.

        (2) Method. Employ a theater-wide distributed C2 construct with deliberate failovers; integrate PACFLT maritime maneuver with PACAF ACE; conduct convoy/escort planning and at-sea sustainment protection; execute airspace control continuity drills under degraded networks; and stress the distribution system with access delays and data integrity injects.

        (3) End state. Joint force demonstrates credible denial posture; C2 remains continuous despite intermittent SATCOM/ISR/PNT; logistics sustains distributed operations with measured throughput and recovery timelines; coalition coordination functions with partial data; and USINDOPACOM delivers a readiness assessment and capability gap recommendations to CJCS NLT 151800Z MAR 2026.

    b. Phases (MDJIR phasing construct aligned to JP 3-0; compressed timeline applied).

        Phase 0 — SHAPE (01–02 MAR 2026): Establish conditions for resilient execution.
            (1) Objectives.
                (a) Establish distributed C2 architecture, alternate nodes, and failover triggers.
                (b) Posture forces for distributed operations and maritime maneuver without signaling uncontrolled escalation.
                (c) Validate information-sharing plan, releasability, and LNO routes.
            (2) Key tasks.
                (a) Stand up MDJIR Joint Coordination Cell (JCC) within JOC; activate alternate/auxiliary C2 sites (designated below) with minimum essential services.
                (b) Publish comm windows and data prioritization tables (mission-essential data elements) per JP 6-0.
                (c) Establish baseline logistics common operating picture (LCOP) and manual backup procedures; rehearse “logistics data integrity compromise” drill.
                (d) Begin signature management posture: emission control measures and reporting discipline.

        Phase 1 — DETER (03–05 MAR 2026): Demonstrate denial posture and rapid reinforcement under friction.
            (1) Objectives.
                (a) Demonstrate credible, distributed combat power and protection of key nodes.
                (b) Exercise joint force entry/reposition with constrained RSOI and political/infrastructure friction.
                (c) Exercise IAMD and airspace control continuity under degraded networks (JP 3-52).
            (2) Key tasks.
                (a) Execute theater-wide reposition event requiring cross-component deconfliction (air/maritime corridors, tanker tracks, amphibious operating areas).
                (b) PACAF executes ACE dispersal to multiple operating locations, including at least two austere/divert locations with reduced comms.
                (c) PACFLT conducts convoy/escort planning drill for high-value logistics movement and at-sea sustainment protection measures.
                (d) Conduct C2 Failover Event #1: scripted loss of primary SATCOM; transition to alternate comm windows and voice/data minimal essential reporting.

        Phase 2 — SEIZE INITIATIVE (06–09 MAR 2026): Operate through disruption; integrate air/maritime/space with degraded support.
            (1) Objectives.
                (a) Maintain operational tempo despite intermittent SATCOM/ISR/PNT and EMS contestation.
                (b) Validate battle drills for degraded space support (alternate PNT; protected SATCOM prioritization).
                (c) Exercise joint targeting/collection synchronization at a procedural level (no target lists), emphasizing kill chain resilience.
            (2) Key tasks.
                (a) Execute “degraded space support” inject lasting 24–48 hours; implement alternate navigation procedures for designated sorties and maritime events.
                (b) Conduct logistics data incident inject: force tracking discrepancies; require reconciliation via manual processes and LNO confirmation.
                (c) Execute distributed maritime operations drill: dynamic routing, deception, and layered defense for logistics shipping (procedural).
                (d) Airspace control continuity: publish and operate on degraded ACO/ACO updates using preplanned measures; demonstrate deconfliction via procedural control if datalinks are degraded (JP 3-52).

        Phase 3 — DOMINATE (10–12 MAR 2026): Demonstrate sustained joint effects generation and base recovery while contested.
            (1) Objectives.
                (a) Sustain distributed operations at scale for 72 hours with measured sortie and replenishment rates.
                (b) Demonstrate base/port recovery and reconstitution (simulated) following adversary strike replication and cyber disruption.
                (c) Validate joint protection posture: IAMD coordination, convoy protection, and C2 survivability.
            (2) Key tasks.
                (a) Execute high-tempo ATO cycle with intermittent connectivity: reliance on comm windows, preplanned mission packages, and decentralized execution authorities.
                (b) Conduct C2 Failover Event #2: degrade primary JOC services; activate auxiliary C2 node as lead for time-bounded execution and reporting.
                (c) Conduct “contested distribution” event: closure/delay of a primary node; shift to alternates; execute throughput reporting and recovery timeline estimates.

        Phase 4 — STABILIZE (13–15 MAR 2026): Consolidate gains, capture lessons, and deliver readiness evidence.
            (1) Objectives.
                (a) Transition from high-tempo operations to assessment and reporting while maintaining readiness.
                (b) Produce CJCS-ready denial posture readiness assessment and capability gap recommendations (CJCSI 3170.01 alignment).
            (2) Key tasks.
                (a) Compile component assessments: C2 resilience, logistics throughput, ACE sustainment, maritime escort performance, airspace control continuity, and coalition interoperability under releasability constraints.
                (b) Conduct hotwash with combined partners (as permitted), capturing interoperability frictions and workarounds.
                (c) Deliver theater assessment brief NLT 151800Z MAR 2026.

    c. Lines of Operation (LOOs).

        LOO 1 — Distributed Denial Posture (Air/Maritime Maneuver).
            (1) Purpose: Deny adversary confidence in rapid fait accompli by complicating targeting and demonstrating credible response options.
            (2) Core activities: PACAF ACE dispersal; bomber tasking package integration (procedural); PACFLT distributed maritime operations; deception and signature management; integrated protection coordination.

        LOO 2 — Resilient Mission Command (C2/Communications/Coalition).
            (1) Purpose: Protect decision advantage and unity of effort under degraded SATCOM and cyber/EMS attack.
            (2) Core activities: distributed C2 nodes; comm windows and mission-essential data prioritization; LNO architecture; procedural airspace control; cross-domain information sharing with releasability controls.

        LOO 3 — Contested Logistics and Endurance (Distribution/Sustainment/Base Recovery).
            (1) Purpose: Sustain operational tempo when logistics data systems are degraded/manipulated and nodes are threatened.
            (2) Core activities: alternate distribution pathways; convoy/escort planning; at-sea replenishment protection; forward arming and refueling concept validation (where authorized); manual LCOP backup; rapid reconstitution drills.

        LOO 4 — Information Advantage Under Degradation (Cyber/Space/EMS Integration).
            (1) Purpose: Fight for information and maintain acceptable targeting/collection fidelity using degraded space support and contested EMS.
            (2) Core activities: alternate PNT and navigation procedures; protected SATCOM prioritization; DCO/incident response; spectrum management; collection synchronization using low-bandwidth methods.

    d. Decisive Points (DPs) for MDJIR assessment.

        DP1 — Distributed C2 Effective Transition.
            Condition: Successful transition to alternate/auxiliary C2 node within established time threshold while maintaining ATO/ACO continuity and command authorities (JP 6-0). Measure: time to re-establish minimum essential C2 services; number of missed/late critical reports; operational impacts.

        DP2 — ACE Sustainment at Austere Locations.
            Condition: Sustained generation of sorties from dispersed/austere locations with reduced comms and constrained fuel/munitions handling. Measure: sortie generation rate vs plan; refuel/rearm cycle times; maintenance recovery; safety deviations.

        DP3 — Contested Distribution Reroute and Recovery.
            Condition: Logistics flow maintained after simulated denial of a primary port/airfield/distribution node and compromise of logistics tracking data. Measure: time to reroute; throughput achieved; inventory accuracy after reconciliation; impact on operational tempo.

        DP4 — Airspace Control Continuity Under Degraded Networks.
            Condition: Airspace deconfliction maintained during datalink disruptions and intermittent SATCOM via procedural measures and preplanned airspace control measures (JP 3-52). Measure: number of deconfliction incidents; timeliness of ACO updates; controller workload and clarity.

        DP5 — Convoy/Escort and At-Sea Sustainment Protection (Procedural).
            Condition: High-value logistics movement planned and executed (exercise) with layered defense and dynamic rerouting under ISR threat replication. Measure: adherence to escort plan; responsiveness to reroute triggers; communications discipline; risk acceptance documentation.

    e. Scheme of maneuver (exercise-level; no target lists; procedural focus).

        (1) Joint Force posture and maneuver.
            (a) Maritime. PACFLT will operate a notional CSG and ESG in dispersed operating areas to validate maritime maneuver, escort concepts, and sea-based sustainment protection. Undersea coordination will emphasize maritime domain awareness and deconfliction with logistics shipping routes.
            (b) Air. PACAF will execute ACE with multiple operating locations to complicate adversary targeting and to validate command relationships and sustainment. A bomber tasking package (BTF-style) will be integrated procedurally to stress tanker planning, airspace control measures, and comm windows.
            (c) Land and littoral. USARPAC and MARFORPAC will support establishment and sustainment of expeditionary logistics nodes and limited, exercise-focused EABO constructs, primarily to stress distribution, communications, and protection coordination.
            (d) Space/cyber/EMS. USSPACECOM support will implement scheduled coverage gaps and PNT degradation injects; USCYBERCOM/Service cyber will run defensive playbooks and incident response to logistics data manipulation scenarios.

        (2) Fires and effects integration (exercise). MDJIR will validate joint processes for integrating effects (air/maritime/cyber/space) at a procedural level: collection management, target development decision points (without target lists), and battle damage/assessment reporting under intermittent connectivity.

        (3) Protection. IAMD coordination will be exercised as a readiness and procedural drill, integrating reporting, warning, and deconfliction measures with allies where authorized. Base/port recovery is simulated to validate decision timing and resource prioritization.

        (4) Information sharing and coalition operations. Combined operations will emphasize: minimal essential information exchange; alternate communications pathways; LNO-enabled coordination; and operation under partial data feeds while preserving releasability constraints.

    g. Coordinating instructions (exercise execution principles).

        (1) No-strike/target lists are not produced. Effects integration is procedural and assessment-focused.

        (2) Communications discipline: implement mission-essential data elements (MEDE) and priority of communications by phase; enforce comm windows and reporting formats to reduce bandwidth requirements.

        (3) Delegated authorities: components will identify and rehearse decentralized execution authorities for time-sensitive safety and deconfliction decisions when connectivity is lost.

        (4) Assessment: each phase includes defined measures of performance (MOP) and measures of effectiveness (MOE) mapped to DPs and LOOs; components will submit daily assessment inputs during comm windows.


6. ADVERSARY COURSES OF ACTION (COAs) (exercise replication; 2–3 COAs).

    COA A — “Rapid Disruption of C2 and Logistics” (Most likely).
        (1) Adversary initiates cyber attacks against unclassified logistics networks and selectively against mission enclaves, generating data integrity issues and delayed movement clearances.
        (2) Concurrent EMS jamming/spoofing degrades data links and GPS in localized windows, timed to ATO/airspace transition periods.
        (3) Counterspace interference produces intermittent SATCOM/ISR gaps, forcing procedural control and manual reporting.
        (4) Objective: slow U.S./combined decision cycle; create perception of disorganization and sustainment fragility.

    COA B — “Maritime Interdiction and ISR Overmatch” (Most dangerous to sustainment).
        (1) Adversary prioritizes persistent ISR (air/maritime/space) and attempts to localize high-value logistics shipping and replenishment events.
        (2) Simulated submarine/surface threats force convoy/escort responses and rerouting, increasing distribution time and fuel burn.
        (3) Objective: impose operational pause by threatening SLOCs and at-sea sustainment, stressing escort availability and communications.

    COA C — “Selective Base/Node Denial and Psychological Pressure” (High political friction).
        (1) Adversary conducts simulated precision strikes against a small set of key nodes (ports/airfields/POL storage) and amplifies the effects via information operations.
        (2) Adversary pairs this with diplomatic coercion and disinformation to generate access delays and movement restrictions.
        (3) Objective: concentrate U.S. operations into fewer nodes (making them more targetable) and strain coalition cohesion.


7. FRIENDLY COURSES OF ACTION (Recommended COA).

    COA 1 — “Distributed Denial with Resilient C2 and Contested Distribution” (RECOMMENDED).

    a. Summary. Execute a theater-wide distributed posture (air and maritime), anchored by resilient mission command and a deliberate contested logistics concept, to demonstrate denial credibility and sustainment endurance under intermittent satellite coverage and degraded networks.

    b. Rationale (JP 5-0). COA 1 directly addresses JSCP priorities: deny adversary fait accompli confidence, protect decision advantage, and sustain contested logistics. It provides measurable DPs and integrates joint capabilities without requiring tactical escalation.

    c. Key elements.
        (1) Distributed C2 architecture with two deliberate failover events; LNO-driven coordination as primary backup.
        (2) ACE dispersal to forward and austere locations with preplanned sortie packages and reduced comms assumptions.
        (3) PACFLT-led convoy/escort planning and distributed maritime operations; at-sea sustainment protection drills.
        (4) Degraded space support battle drills and alternate PNT procedures across air and maritime operations.
        (5) Logistics resilience: reroute plan, manual LCOP, and data integrity incident response.

    d. Risk and mitigation (exercise).
        (1) Risk: overextension of tankers and mobility assets reduces realism or safety margins. Mitigation: enforce tanker prioritization by phase; cap sortie surges; rehearse abort/divert procedures.
        (2) Risk: coalition information-sharing constraints slow coordination. Mitigation: publish releasable MEDE sets; use LNO channels and comm windows; pre-coordinate procedural airspace measures.
        (3) Risk: excessive complexity in failover events causes loss of learning objectives. Mitigation: define minimum essential services, clear triggers, and time-bounded failover periods; focus on continuity not perfection.


8. FORCE REQUIREMENTS (General categories; refined in OPLAN and sourcing conferences).

    a. Maneuver forces.
        (1) One CSG and one ESG (or functionally equivalent naval task groups) to enable distributed maritime operations and escort drills.
        (2) 8–10 fighter squadrons (4th/5th gen mix) for ACE dispersal and airspace control stress.
        (3) 1–2 bomber tasking packages integrated procedurally to stress long-range planning, tanker coordination, and airspace measures.

    b. Enablers.
        (1) Tankers sufficient to support distributed operations, with priority to defensive counterair, maritime strike integration drills, and mobility corridors.
        (2) Strategic and theater airlift to support RSOI under friction and sustain forward/austere nodes.
        (3) ISR (air/maritime) with assumptions of partial feeds; focus on MDA and distribution protection.
        (4) EW/EMS management capabilities to operate through jamming and degraded links.

    c. Protection and resilience.
        (1) IAMD coordination elements (joint and combined) to exercise warning, reporting, and engagement coordination procedures.
        (2) Base defense and expeditionary security elements for forward/austere locations (exercise scope).
        (3) Cyber protection teams/incident response for logistics networks and mission enclaves.
        (4) Space support coordination for protected SATCOM prioritization and alternate PNT battle drills.

    d. Command and control.
        (1) JTF-capable staff augmentation for JOC, JCC, and functional cells (JFMCC/JFACC synchronization, logistics, cyber/space).
        (2) LNO teams: component-to-component, combined LNOs where permitted, and logistics LNOs to key nodes.
        (3) Deployable/transportable comm packages to support alternate/auxiliary C2 nodes and austere locations.

    e. Capability gaps and JCIDS linkage (CJCSI 3170.01).
        (1) Components will document: (a) communications shortfalls; (b) logistics data integrity vulnerabilities; (c) PNT-denied procedure gaps; (d) tanker/mobility limitations; and (e) coalition interoperability constraints, with recommended DOTMLPF-P actions for follow-on validation.


9. LOGISTICS CONCEPT (JP 4-0; contested distribution emphasis).

    a. Logistics intent. Sustain distributed operations for 15 days under contested logistics conditions by using multiple distribution pathways, prioritizing critical commodities, and maintaining an auditable manual fallback when logistics IT and satellite connectivity are degraded.

    b. Distribution framework.

        (1) Multi-node network. Use a tiered distribution concept:
            (a) Strategic entry nodes (limited number; higher throughput; higher risk).
            (b) Theater distribution hubs (multiple; shiftable based on threat and access).
            (c) Expeditionary logistics nodes (ELNs) supporting ACE forward/austere operations with prepositioned kits and constrained stockage.
        (2) Dynamic routing. Establish triggers for rerouting (node closure, threat replication, data integrity concern, clearance delay) and pre-identified alternates for air and sea movement.
        (3) Convoy/escort procedures. PACFLT leads planning for high-value sealift movements and at-sea replenishment protection (exercise), integrating comm windows and reporting discipline to reduce ISR exposure.

    c. Supply priorities (planning guidance).

        (1) Priority 1: aviation fuel, tanker support sustainment, and POL distribution continuity (aviation and maritime).
        (2) Priority 2: critical munitions handling (exercise representation), spare parts with high mission impact, and runway/airfield repair consumables (simulated).
        (3) Priority 3: food/water/medical sustainment for forward/austere detachments.
        (4) Priority 4: construction/barrier materials supporting expeditionary resilience.

    d. Maintenance and reconstitution.

        (1) Forward maintenance. PACAF and MARFORPAC will validate forward maintenance and cannibalization controls (exercise) under data system degradation.
        (2) Reconstitution drills. Simulate base recovery after replicated strikes: runway closure timelines, ramp clearance, fuel system checks, and sortie re-generation decisions.
        (3) Maritime sustainment. Validate replenishment planning, consumption reporting via comm windows, and risk-informed scheduling.

    e. Data integrity and manual LCOP fallback.

        (1) Assumption: logistics tracking data will be manipulated or partially unavailable.
        (2) Required battle drill: reconcile shipments and inventories using (a) manual logs; (b) LNO confirmation; (c) periodic “truth” checks during comm windows; and (d) cross-validation from mobility departure/arrival records.
        (3) Reporting: daily logistics posture report in MEDE format (fuel, critical parts, throughput constraints, node status, distribution delays) with time-stamped confidence level (high/medium/low).

    f. Measures (logistics MOP/MOE examples).
        (1) Time to reroute after node denial; throughput maintained as percent of plan.
        (2) Fuel days-of-supply at forward/austere nodes; number of sorties impacted by POL shortfalls.
        (3) Inventory record accuracy after incident inject; time to restore trusted data set.
        (4) Sealift/airlift schedule adherence under clearance delays; variance and cause coding.

    g. Environmental and safety constraints. All logistics operations will comply with host-nation regulations, SOFA constraints, safety requirements, and hazardous material handling standards. The exercise will not compel unsafe operations to meet scenario objectives.


10. COMMAND AND CONTROL (JP 3-0; JP 6-0; JP 3-52).

    a. Command relationships (exercise).

        (1) CDRUSINDOPACOM retains combatant command authority (COCOM) as applicable and exercises operational control through designated functional/component commanders in accordance with standing command relationships.

        (2) Functional coordination. The JOC will synchronize JFMCC/JFACC operations, logistics, cyber, and space support via the MDJIR Joint Coordination Cell (JCC). Components will maintain organic command while adhering to theater comm windows and reporting standards.

        (3) Supported/supporting transitions. Triggers for supported/supporting shifts (e.g., primary focus on logistics protection vs airspace control continuity) will be pre-briefed in Phase 0 and rehearsed during failover events.

    b. Distributed C2 construct.

        (1) Primary. Theater JOC with integrated planning and current operations, including a resilient communications plan with prioritized services.

        (2) Alternate and auxiliary. Establish designated alternate/auxiliary C2 nodes with minimum essential services, able to assume time-bounded lead for execution if primary services degrade beyond thresholds.

        (3) Failover triggers (examples; finalize in execution order).
            (a) Loss of SATCOM beyond a defined duration affecting ATO/ACO transmission.
            (b) Cyber incident causing loss of integrity in COP/LCOP.
            (c) Facility/service outage impacting ability to produce or disseminate time-sensitive guidance.
        (4) Failover success criteria. Restoration of: (a) voice command net; (b) airspace control measures dissemination (procedural if required); (c) logistics priority guidance; and (d) consolidated assessment reporting.

    c. Communications plan (high level).

        (1) Operate with intermittent SATCOM: publish daily comm windows, prioritized by phase and mission type.

        (2) Mission-essential data elements (MEDE) prioritization (examples).
            Priority A: safety of flight/navigation advisories, airspace control measures, time-sensitive deconfliction.
            Priority B: logistics node status and movement priorities, tanker allocations, medevac coordination.
            Priority C: assessment summaries and lessons learned inputs.

        (3) Procedural control. When datalinks are degraded, airspace control will shift to preplanned procedural measures (JP 3-52), with published altitude blocks, routing structures, and timing control measures as required.

        (4) Coalition communications. Provide releasable products and MEDE sets; rely on LNOs and scheduled exchanges; avoid dependence on continuous high-bandwidth feeds.

    d. Cyber defense and incident response integration (JP 3-12).

        (1) Defensive posture. Prioritize protection of: (a) mission command networks; (b) airspace control planning systems; (c) logistics planning/tracking; and (d) identity and access management.

        (2) Incident response. Execute at least one major incident inject affecting logistics data integrity; require containment, eradication, recovery, and restoration of trusted data sets, with commander decision points on risk acceptance for continued operations.

        (3) Reporting. Cyber incidents reported via MEDE with confidence levels and operational impact statements.

    e. Space support coordination.

        (1) Degraded space battle drills. USSPACECOM supporting elements will implement scheduled gaps; components will execute alternate PNT procedures and protected SATCOM prioritization.

        (2) Navigation and timing. Validate PNT-denied navigation procedures for designated air and maritime events; report deviations and safety impacts.

    f. Assessment and lessons learned.

        (1) Assessment framework (JP 5-0). Map MOP/MOE to LOOs and DPs; collect daily during comm windows; conduct phase-end reviews.

        (2) Lessons learned and capability gaps. Document gaps with DOTMLPF-P framing and recommended next steps aligned to CJCSI 3170.01; identify which gaps require follow-on experimentation vs near-term TTP updates.

        (3) Deliverable. Theater denial posture readiness assessment and resilience summary brief to CJCS NLT 151800Z MAR 2026, including: key findings, quantified impacts, mitigations, and prioritized recommendations.


11. TASK ORGANIZATION AND COORDINATION (immediate planning actions).

    a. J5 (lead). Publish MDJIR operational design summary, phasing matrix, and assessment plan aligned to this CONPLAN; coordinate with components for ORBAT and daily battle rhythm.

    b. J3 (lead execution). Establish JCC; publish failover triggers and minimum essential services list; coordinate daily ATO/ACO cycle adaptations for comm windows.

    c. J4 (lead logistics). Publish contested distribution concept annex: node categorization, reroute triggers, throughput reporting formats, and manual LCOP procedures; coordinate convoy/escort planning inputs with PACFLT.

    d. J6 (lead communications). Publish comm windows, MEDE list, and alternate communication pathways; validate deployable comm packages for alternate/auxiliary nodes and austere locations.

    e. J2/J39 (information environment). Coordinate adversary ISR replication assumptions, signature management guidance, and information frictions to support exercise realism.

    f. Components. Provide:
        (1) ACE plan (PACAF) with sustainment assumptions and diversion procedures.
        (2) Maritime escort/convoy and replenishment protection plan (PACFLT).
        (3) ELN/EABO support concept (MARFORPAC) and land distribution support concept (USARPAC).
        (4) LNO roster, roles, and minimum essential coordination requirements (all components).
        (5) Cyber incident response playbooks and reporting templates (Service cyber/USCYBERCOM supporting).


12. SUMMARY.

    This CONPLAN operationalizes JSCP MDJIR priorities into a phased, measurable concept that stresses distributed denial posture, resilient mission command, and contested logistics endurance under intermittent satellite coverage and degraded networks. Execution of this concept will generate CJCS-relevant readiness evidence, validated battle drills, and prioritized capability gap recommendations aligned with joint doctrine (JP 5-0, JP 3-0, JP 3-52) and JCIDS processes (CJCSI 3170.01).

strategies.title: INDOPACOM — Western Pacific Operations Plan — Operation INDOPACOM SHIELD OPLAN
strategies.content:
MEMORANDUM FOR: COMMANDER, UNITED STATES INDO-PACIFIC COMMAND

FROM: DIRECTOR, PLANS (J5), UNITED STATES INDO-PACIFIC COMMAND

SUBJECT: OPLAN (U) — Western Pacific Multi-Domain Joint Integration and Resilience (MDJIR) (1–15 March 2026)

DATE: 01 MAR 2026

CLASSIFICATION: UNCLASSIFIED // FOUO

REFERENCES:
a. Memorandum, CJCS, “JSCP — INDOPACOM Western Pacific Multi-Domain Joint Integration and Resilience (MDJIR) Tasking (1–15 March 2026),” dated 01 MAR 2026.
b. NMS Theater Annex — Western Pacific (INDOPACOM) Multi-Domain Joint Integration and Resilience, effective 01–15 MAR 2026.
c. JP 5-0, Joint Planning.
d. JP 3-0, Joint Operations.
e. JP 3-30, Joint Air Operations.
f. JP 3-52, Joint Airspace Control.
g. JP 4-0, Joint Logistics.
h. JP 6-0, Joint Communications System.
i. JP 3-12, Cyberspace Operations.
j. CJCSI 3170.01, Joint Capabilities Integration and Development System (JCIDS).
k. Standing theater access agreements, SOFAs, and applicable national caveats (as provided by USINDOPACOM J8/J5 country desk and J35).

NOTE (FOR EXERCISE DESIGN / NON-EXECUTABLE): This OPLAN is a notional exercise-planning document intended to guide simulation design, staff battle drills, and readiness assessment under JP 5-0. It deliberately avoids real-world unit identifiers, installation names, precise movement timelines, routing, and other execution-level details that could be misused. Locations are expressed as “Primary Operating Base (POB), Forward Operating Site (FOS),” and “Expeditionary Logistics Node (ELN)” placeholders to be mapped by the exercise control group (EXCON) to the “available real-world bases in theater” list (not provided in the tasking message).

1. (U) SITUATION.

   a. (U) General. From 010000Z MAR 2026 through 152359Z MAR 2026, USINDOPACOM conducts MDJIR in the Western Pacific to validate joint force integration and resilience in a contested information environment characterized by intermittent satellite communications (SATCOM) coverage gaps, degraded position/navigation/timing (PNT), data-link interference, and contested logistics. The exercise replicates a near-peer Pacific adversary’s A2/AD effects through simulated injects and adjudicated outcomes; it does not constitute a real-world contingency and does not authorize lethal operations.

   b. (U) Adversary forces (exercise replication). The adversary is modeled as a near-peer state actor capable of: long-range anti-ship and land-attack strike complexes; integrated air and missile defense (IAMD) effects; maritime and undersea disruption of sea lines of communication (SLOC); cyber operations focused on logistics and unclassified networks; electronic attack affecting tactical data links and GPS; and reversible counterspace interference producing intermittent SATCOM outages and ISR degradation. The adversary’s most likely approach during MDJIR is to contest decision advantage by attempting to disrupt joint C2 continuity and degrade distribution throughput (fuel, munitions, and mission-essential spares) by targeting visible nodes and data systems.

   c. (U) Friendly forces.

      (1) Supported commander. CDRUSINDOPACOM is supported for MDJIR execution.

      (2) Supporting commanders and components. PACFLT, PACAF, MARFORPAC, USARPAC, SOCPAC, and supporting USSPACECOM/USCYBERCOM (and Service cyber/space components) provide forces and capabilities to execute the exercise objectives consistent with apportionment and standing authorities.

      (3) Combined/allied/partner forces (exercise). Participation is governed by existing agreements and national caveats. Combined coordination is assumed to include limited shared airspace control measures where authorized; information-sharing with releasability constraints; intermittent connectivity; and partner operations with partial data feeds and separate mission networks.

   d. (U) Assumptions.

      (1) Access, basing, and overflight are available consistent with standing agreements; EXCON will apply delays, partial denials, or restrictions as injects to stress planning and re-planning.
      (2) Satellite coverage gaps occur in multiple windows (hours-to-days) and require C2/ISR/PNT degradation battle drills.
      (3) Cyber incidents affect primarily non-classified and mission support networks (e.g., movement and distribution visibility, maintenance and supply transactions), forcing manual reversion and data integrity validation.
      (4) No real-world rules of engagement (ROE) changes are implied. “Fires” and “effects” are simulated and adjudicated.

   e. (U) Constraints and restraints.

      (1) Constraint: Operations are executed as an exercise with simulated effects; no lethal targeting, no real-world kinetic action.
      (2) Restraint: Protect partner information and comply with releasability rules; employ minimum necessary classification; maintain operations security (OPSEC) consistent with exercise play.

   f. (U) Operational environment considerations.

      (1) Geography/tyranny of distance. Distributed basing and long-range maritime maneuver impose time-distance constraints on sorties, refueling, and sealift; these factors will be used to stress endurance and recovery timelines.
      (2) Infrastructure limitations. Austere locations have constrained ramp space, fuel storage, cargo handling, and air defense capacity; throughput limits will be modeled and measured.
      (3) Information environment. Periodic loss of beyond-line-of-sight (BLOS) transport and degraded PNT require disciplined emissions control (EMCON), alternate comm paths (HF, LOS relay, mesh), and mission command.

2. (U) MISSION.

USINDOPACOM conducts MDJIR (010000Z MAR 2026 through 152359Z MAR 2026) in the Western Pacific to demonstrate and assess multi-domain joint force integration and resilience by: (1) sustaining distributed air and maritime combat power generation under contested logistics; (2) maintaining mission command and coalition coordination under intermittent SATCOM coverage gaps, degraded PNT, and cyber/EMS disruption; and (3) producing a readiness assessment and capability gap recommendations to CJCS/OSD NLT 151800Z MAR 2026 in accordance with JP 5-0, JP 3-0, JP 3-52, JP 4-0, JP 6-0, JP 3-12, and CJCSI 3170.01.

3. (U) EXECUTION.

   a. (U) Commander’s Intent.

      (1) Purpose. Validate that the joint force can preserve decision advantage and operational endurance in the Western Pacific while operating from a distributed posture and under degraded space/cyber/EMS conditions.

      (2) Method. Employ a theater-wide distributed C2 architecture with pre-planned failovers; integrate PACFLT maritime maneuver with PACAF Agile Combat Employment (ACE) and dynamic airspace control; employ expeditionary logistics nodes and afloat sustainment protection; conduct repeated battle drills for SATCOM/PNT/data-link loss; and stress the distribution enterprise using injects (access delays, data integrity compromise, and throughput constraints). Execute mission-type orders and commander’s intent-driven control when connectivity is degraded, consistent with JP 3-0 and JP 6-0.

      (3) End state. Joint force demonstrates: (a) credible denial posture through distributed basing and integrated maritime maneuver; (b) continuous C2 despite intermittent SATCOM/ISR/PNT; (c) sustainment throughput sufficient to maintain planned sortie and presence rates with measured recovery timelines; (d) coalition coordination functioning under partial data; and (e) documented lessons learned and capability gap recommendations delivered to CJCS/OSD by 151800Z MAR 2026.

   b. (U) Scheme of Maneuver.

      (1) Operational approach. MDJIR executes through five compressed phases aligned to JP 3-0. Maneuver is executed across air and maritime domains with enabling space/cyber and a contested logistics problem set. “Maneuver” in this exercise emphasizes posture, dispersal, protection, and the ability to reconstitute and continue operations rather than offensive destruction.

      (2) Phasing construct (time-bound for exercise control; specific event timing is scenario-driven and may flex).

         Phase 0 — SHAPE (01–02 MAR 2026): Establish resilient execution conditions.
         Objectives:
           (a) Stand up distributed C2 (primary/alternate/contingency/emergency) with failover triggers and communications playbooks.
           (b) Posture air and maritime forces to distributed locations; validate ACE site certification packages and airfield/port operating constraints.
           (c) Establish combined coordination mechanisms and releasability pathways; rehearse cross-domain coordination cells.
           (d) Confirm logistics baselines: fuel, munitions, spares, medical, and intra-theater lift availability; validate manual reversion procedures.

         Phase I — DETER / DISPERSE (03–05 MAR 2026): Demonstrate denial posture and complicate adversary targeting.
         Objectives:
           (a) Execute ACE dispersal to multiple FOS/CLs (contingency locations) with signature management measures.
           (b) Establish maritime maneuver patterns supporting SLOC defense and distributed sea-based logistics.
           (c) Initiate airspace control continuity drills (ACO/ACM procedures) under degraded data links.
           (d) Begin contested logistics injects (limited access, throughput reduction, cyber impacts to tracking systems).

         Phase II — CONTEST C2 / LOGISTICS (06–09 MAR 2026): Operate through SATCOM gaps and cyber/EMS disruption.
         Objectives:
           (a) Execute pre-planned C2 failovers (JFACC/JFMCC/JFLCC supporting nodes) and demonstrate mission continuation on mission-type orders.
           (b) Employ alternate comms (HF, LOS relay, airborne gateway, tactical chat equivalents) and prioritize protected SATCOM when available.
           (c) Validate degraded PNT procedures (alternate nav, timing discipline, TACAN/ILS where applicable, celestial/INS practices as simulated).
           (d) Continue sorties/presence while sustaining distribution under compromised data integrity (manual verification, reconciliation, controlled release of parts/fuel).

         Phase III — REGAIN TEMPO / RECONSTITUTE (10–13 MAR 2026): Recover and sustain operational tempo after disruption.
         Objectives:
           (a) Reconstitute C2 systems and data integrity; restore common operational picture (COP) with confidence scoring and provenance.
           (b) Execute rapid airfield/base recovery drills (simulated damage, runway/ramp constraints) and adjust sortie generation plan.
           (c) Demonstrate convoy/escort planning and at-sea sustainment protection; manage risk to high-value logistics shipping.
           (d) Conduct integrated air/maritime “presence surges” within realistic tanker and sustainment constraints.

         Phase IV — ASSESS / TRANSITION (14–15 MAR 2026): Capture lessons, assess readiness, provide recommendations.
         Objectives:
           (a) Collect measures of effectiveness (MOE) and measures of performance (MOP) across C2 continuity, sortie rates, logistics throughput, and coalition coordination.
           (b) Produce capability gap recommendations (DOTMLPF-P) consistent with CJCSI 3170.01.
           (c) Transition to steady-state posture and complete after-action reporting to CJCS/OSD NLT 151800Z MAR 2026.

      (3) Joint air scheme (exercise). The JFACC (as designated by CDRUSINDOPACOM) will execute a notional ATO cycle with deliberate “degraded cycle” drills: shortened planning windows, partial data, and manual coordination. Primary air tasks include defensive counterair (DCA), maritime strike integration (simulated), ISR presence (simulated feeds with dropouts), tanker management under threat replication, aeromedical evacuation rehearsal, and intra-theater lift for ACE.

      (4) Joint maritime scheme (exercise). The JFMCC (as designated) will employ distributed maritime operations constructs to: protect SLOCs; escort logistics shipping; conduct undersea coordination; and provide sea-based sustainment and C2 redundancy. Maneuver emphasizes complicating adversary ISR, maintaining logistics flow, and enabling air operations via afloat refueling/rearming where exercised.

      (5) Space/cyber/EMS integration. USSPACECOM support will prioritize protected SATCOM allocation during windows of interference, coordinate alternate ISR dissemination paths, and lead PNT degradation battle drills. USCYBERCOM/Service cyber will prioritize defensive cyber operations (DCO), incident response, and data integrity restoration for movement/distribution and mission planning systems. EMS management will emphasize spectrum deconfliction, emissions discipline, and preplanned comm windows.

      (6) Coordinating instructions (exercise-wide).
         (a) Decision points: C2 failover triggers; shift from network-dependent control to mission-type orders; logistics release authorities under data uncertainty; airspace control under data-link degradation.
         (b) Risk acceptance: Use commander-approved risk matrices for tanker employment, high-value maritime logistics exposure, and communications emissions.
         (c) Measures: Track C2 uptime by node; time-to-failover; sortie generation vs. plan; fuel days-of-supply at POB/FOS/ELN; mean time to restore logistics data confidence; convoy cycle times; and coalition information-sharing timeliness.

   c. (U) Tasks to Subordinate Commands.

      (1) PACFLT (JFMCC-designate).
         (a) Plan and execute distributed maritime operations (DMO) in support of SLOC defense and logistics shipping protection (exercise).
         (b) Establish maritime C2 redundancy and a maritime common operational picture that can operate with intermittent SATCOM.
         (c) Conduct undersea deconfliction procedures (exercise) and integrate with airspace control measures for maritime patrol and ASW training.
         (d) Coordinate convoy/escort rehearsals and replenishment-at-sea protection drills; provide feedback on logistics risk drivers and mitigation.

      (2) PACAF (JFACC-designate).
         (a) Execute ACE dispersal across designated POB/FOS locations; validate minimum operating capabilities (MOC) packages and “hub-and-spoke” sustainment.
         (b) Produce ATO/ACO products with deliberate degraded planning drills; maintain continuity of airspace control per JP 3-52.
         (c) Manage tanker allocation under threat replication and comm degradation; rehearse dynamic retasking and rejoin procedures under degraded data links.
         (d) Coordinate base defense and airfield recovery drills (simulated damage) with host-nation and joint partners.

      (3) MARFORPAC.
         (a) Establish expeditionary advanced base operations (EABO) vignettes at designated littoral training areas (exercise) and integrate with maritime and air C2.
         (b) Provide expeditionary air defense, sensing, and sustainment elements (simulated effects) in support of distributed posture.
         (c) Operate expeditionary logistics nodes (ELNs) to support ACE and littoral operations; rehearse rapid displacement and signature management.

      (4) USARPAC (JFLCC-designate if directed).
         (a) Provide theater sustainment posture and distribution management in coordination with J4 and component logisticians; rehearse contested distribution decision-making per JP 4-0.
         (b) Integrate multi-domain effects coordination (exercise) with joint targeting/effects boards; provide land-based air/missile defense coordination inject response (simulated).
         (c) Operate staging and onward movement nodes (notional) and support host-nation coordination as directed.

      (5) SOCPAC.
         (a) Provide liaison elements to enhance joint/combined coordination, especially during comm degraded periods.
         (b) Support low-signature reconnaissance/sensing concept experimentation (exercise) consistent with OPSEC and releasability.
         (c) Assist in personnel recovery (PR) planning and rehearsal (exercise), including comm-out procedures.

      (6) USSPACECOM (supporting).
         (a) Execute degraded space support battle drills, including SATCOM prioritization recommendations and alternate ISR dissemination.
         (b) Coordinate PNT resilience procedures and timing discipline measures for joint C2 nodes (exercise).
         (c) Provide space-related inject adjudication support and collect lessons learned for resilience gaps.

      (7) USCYBERCOM / Service cyber components (supporting).
         (a) Conduct DCO and incident response rehearsals for mission and mission-support networks; coordinate with J6 and component network operations centers.
         (b) Lead data integrity remediation playbooks for logistics and planning systems; establish “data confidence” scoring and release criteria.
         (c) Provide assessments of cyber readiness gaps and recommendations consistent with CJCSI 3170.01.

4. (U) FIRES (EXERCISE EFFECTS, TARGETING PRIORITIES, ROE CONSTRAINTS).

   a. (U) Purpose. Fires in MDJIR are simulated and focused on training the joint targeting process, cross-domain effects synchronization, and command decision-making under uncertainty, consistent with JP 3-0 and joint targeting doctrine, without generating real-world target lists.

   b. (U) Targeting priorities (effects-based, non-kinetic/kinetic simulated).

      Priority 1: Preserve joint force mission command.
      (1) Protect primary/alternate C2 nodes; maintain communications pathways; ensure airspace control continuity.
      (2) Prioritize counter-ISR and deception/survivability effects (exercise injects) to reduce adversary targeting confidence.

      Priority 2: Sustain distributed combat power generation.
      (1) Protect/restore logistics nodes (fuel distribution, munitions handling, spares pipelines) and maintain acceptable throughput.
      (2) Prioritize base recovery and continuity effects to restore sortie generation after simulated strikes.

      Priority 3: Protect SLOCs and high-value logistics shipping.
      (1) Integrate maritime escort, air cover, and undersea coordination (exercise) to reduce logistics interruption.
      (2) Prioritize detection and tracking of simulated adversary maritime threats in key transit areas.

      Priority 4: Demonstrate credible denial posture.
      (1) Execute integrated air/maritime presence and responsive maneuver to complicate adversary planning.
      (2) Conduct simulated long-range and maritime strike integration events for staff proficiency, without real-world targeting.

   c. (U) ROE constraints (exercise).

      (1) No authorization for real-world kinetic engagement. All engagements/effects are simulated, adjudicated, and controlled by EXCON.
      (2) No real-world target folders, coordinates, or vulnerable infrastructure lists will be produced in this OPLAN. Exercise targets are represented as generic “Objective Sets” (e.g., “Integrated Air Defense Node,” “Maritime Surveillance Node,” “Logistics Disruption Vector”) to train processes.
      (3) Information operations and cyber effects are limited to exercise networks and approved training environments. No activity will target real-world civilian infrastructure.

   d. (U) Coordination.

      (1) Joint Effects/Targeting Board (JETB) will synchronize component requests for effects with the ATO cycle and maritime scheme, with explicit deconfliction under comm-degraded conditions.
      (2) Space and cyber representatives will provide feasibility, risk, and timing inputs; J6 will coordinate spectrum and comm impacts.

5. (U) FORCE SIZING (NOTIONAL FOR EXERCISE; TO BE MAPPED TO AVAILABLE BASES BY EXCON).

   a. (U) Air domain forces (notional).

      (1) Notional Expeditionary Fighter Wing 1 (EFW-1): Approximately 24x 5th-generation multirole fighters (e.g., F-35-class). Deploy from POB-1 with planned dispersal detachments of 4–6 aircraft to two FOS locations (FOS-A and FOS-B). Primary mission: DCA/OCA (simulated), counter-maritime air support (simulated), and resilient sortie generation under ACE. EFW-1 will serve as the primary ACE learning unit, emphasizing hot-pit refuel, rapid rearm, and maintenance under limited parts visibility.

      (2) Notional Expeditionary Fighter Wing 2 (EFW-2): Approximately 18–24x air superiority fighters (e.g., F-15/F-22-class). Deploy from POB-2 with a small detachment to FOS-C as comm conditions allow. Primary mission: DCA escort, defensive sweep (simulated), and protection of tanker tracks and maritime logistics corridors under IADS replication.

      (3) Notional Expeditionary Strike Wing (ESW-1): Approximately 18–24x multirole fighters optimized for maritime strike integration (e.g., F/A-18E/F-class or equivalent). Deploy from POB-3 and rotate to FOS-A during Phase II to stress re-planning under SATCOM loss. Primary mission: simulated maritime strike integration, maritime surface search coordination with JFMCC, and flexible response drills.

      (4) Airborne early warning and battle management detachment: Approximately 2–3x AEW&C aircraft (e.g., E-3/E-7-class as notional equivalents), operating from POB-1/POB-2 based on ramp and supportability. Primary mission: air battle management (ABM) and degraded-link airspace control drills; alternate: act as airborne comm relay/gateway when SATCOM is denied.

      (5) ISR detachment: Approximately 4–6x medium-altitude ISR aircraft and/or unmanned ISR equivalents (simulated feeds), operating from POB-2 and an austere FOS as feasible. Primary mission: provide intermittent ISR inputs consistent with space coverage gaps; practice ISR PED (processing, exploitation, dissemination) under bandwidth and classification limits.

      (6) Air mobility forces: A notional air mobility group consisting of approximately 12–16x intra- and inter-theater airlift aircraft (C-130/C-17-class mix) operating from POB-4 with routine sorties into FOS/ELN locations. Primary mission: ACE movement, aeromedical evacuation rehearsal, and sustainment distribution under contested airspace procedures.

      (7) Tanker task force: Approximately 12–18x tanker aircraft (KC-46/KC-135-class mix) staged primarily from POB-5 with contingency operations from POB-2 as required. Primary mission: enable fighter persistence and mobility, execute tanker risk management under threat replication, and rehearse comm-degraded rendezvous, alternates, and recovery.

      (8) Combat support enablers: Contingency response, civil engineering, EOD, security forces, medical, and communications packages sufficient to open/operate 3–4 FOS sites and 1–2 ELNs concurrently. These teams will be distributed with a hub-and-spoke concept, emphasizing minimum essential footprint and rapid displacement.

   b. (U) Maritime domain forces (notional).

      (1) Carrier Strike Group (CSG-1) (notional): One aircraft carrier with an embarked carrier air wing of approximately 44–50 aircraft (fighter, electronic attack, airborne early warning, rotary wing) operating in a broad maneuver area east of the First Island Chain (exact operating areas determined by EXCON for scenario realism). Primary mission: provide sea-based airpower generation, contribute to air defense and maritime presence, and serve as a resilient C2 and logistics node when shore basing is constrained.

      (2) Expeditionary Strike Group (ESG-1) (notional): One amphibious assault ship (LHA/LHD-class) with a notional embarked Marine air-ground task force (MAGTF) element and a composite aviation detachment (approximately 16–20 aircraft/tiltrotor/rotary wing mix). Operating area: littoral training areas and sea lines supporting EABO vignettes (as directed). Primary mission: support expeditionary basing concepts, sea-based logistics, and crisis response drills under comm degradation.

      (3) Destroyer Squadron (DESRON-1) (notional): 4–6 guided-missile destroyers operating as distributed surface action elements. Operating areas: (a) SLOC protection corridors; (b) maritime chokepoint approaches; and (c) screen zones for high-value units and logistics convoys. Primary mission: integrated air and missile defense (simulated), maritime escort, and maritime domain awareness contributions with intermittent connectivity.

      (4) Logistics/Support Squadron (notional): 2–3 fleet replenishment oilers and 1–2 dry cargo/ammunition ships operating on distributed replenishment routes (scenario-driven, not specified here). Primary mission: sustain afloat forces and provide at-sea refueling/replenishment drills while practicing protection measures and deception under adversary ISR replication.

      (5) Submarine Squadron (SUBRON-1) (notional): 3–4 attack submarines operating in assigned undersea boxes (exercise-defined). Primary mission: simulated sea denial, adversary surface/subsurface threat replication, and undersea ISR contributions coordinated through JFMCC with strict OPSEC.

      (6) Maritime patrol detachment: Approximately 6–8x maritime patrol aircraft (P-8-class) operating from POB-6 and/or POB-2 depending on support. Primary mission: ASW/ASuW coordination (exercise), SLOC surveillance, and cueing for convoy protection with realistic comm constraints.

   c. (U) Space/cyber/EMS enabling forces (notional).

      (1) Space support element: A joint space support team integrated into the JOC and component centers to manage SATCOM prioritization, space ISR requests, and PNT degradation procedures.
      (2) Cyber protection teams / incident response: Mission teams aligned to J6 and logistics systems owners to execute defensive cyber and restoration playbooks.
      (3) Spectrum operations cell: A joint EMS cell to coordinate spectrum deconfliction, EW inject responses, and comm windows discipline.

6. (U) LOGISTICS (CONTESTED DISTRIBUTION EMPHASIS; JP 4-0).

   a. (U) Concept. Sustainment will be executed via a distributed support concept that combines: (1) a limited number of POB hubs with higher-capacity stockage and maintenance; (2) multiple FOS locations supported by “push packages” and scheduled resupply; (3) ELNs for transload, refuel, and limited repair; and (4) afloat sustainment to reduce reliance on fixed shore nodes. The logistics scheme is designed to function with degraded asset visibility, intermittent communications, and compromised data integrity.

   b. (U) Priorities of sustainment.
      (1) POL (aviation fuel, ship fuel) distribution continuity and storage resilience.
      (2) Munitions handling and safe storage (simulated expenditure accounting).
      (3) Mission-critical spares for sortie generation (engines, tires/brakes, avionics line replaceable units).
      (4) Medical readiness and casualty care (exercise scenarios).
      (5) Base operating support for ACE sites (power, water, airfield services, security).

   c. (U) Distribution and movement (exercise).
      (1) Use a layered delivery model: scheduled airlift to POB hubs; onward distribution by intra-theater lift to FOS/ELN; and sealift for heavy sustainment with convoy/escort rehearsals.
      (2) Implement “data integrity gates” for release of high-risk shipments when logistics IT systems are degraded: manual validation, two-person verification, and reconciliation with physical inventories.
      (3) Plan for surge-and-recover logistics rhythms rather than constant flow during Phase II (SATCOM gaps), emphasizing prepositioned push packages and local stockage.

   d. (U) Maintenance and repair.
      (1) Emphasize forward maintenance limited to safe, high-payoff tasks; evacuate complex repairs to POB hubs or afloat capability as exercised.
      (2) Use cannibalization controls and strict configuration management when automated systems are unavailable.

   e. (U) Medical.
      (1) Provide role-based care at POB hubs with forward aid capability at FOS/ELN; rehearse aeromedical evacuation under comm-degraded conditions and alternate routing.
      (2) Implement medical logistics tracking with manual back-up and daily reconciliation.

   f. (U) Contracting and host-nation support (exercise).
      (1) Employ host-nation support within agreements; EXCON may replicate disruptions (labor constraints, access limits).
      (2) Contracting officers will rehearse continuity under cyber incidents affecting payment, ordering, and vendor communications (exercise injects only).

   g. (U) Logistics reporting (battle rhythm).
      (1) Establish a minimum essential logistics reporting set that can be transmitted via low-bandwidth means during SATCOM gaps.
      (2) Require daily (or event-driven) commander’s critical information requirements (CCIR)-linked logistics updates: fuel state, sortie capability, munitions posture (simulated), and distribution delays.

7. (U) COMMAND AND CONTROL (JP 6-0; JP 3-52).

   a. (U) C2 architecture. MDJIR employs a distributed mission command construct: a primary Joint Operations Center (JOC), an alternate JOC, and component operations centers with preplanned succession and failover. The JFACC/JFMCC/JFLCC (as designated) maintain mission execution capability when connectivity to the primary JOC is degraded.

   b. (U) C2 objectives.
      (1) Maintain continuity of command and clarity of commander’s intent under degraded communications.
      (2) Preserve airspace control and safety of flight under intermittent data links.
      (3) Maintain a credible COP with confidence scoring and provenance tracking.

   c. (U) Communications plan (resilience).
      (1) Primary communications: standard theater networks as available (exercise).
      (2) Alternate communications: HF voice/data, LOS relays, airborne gateway/relay concepts, courier/physical transfer for critical products when required, and preplanned comm windows.
      (3) Emergency communications: minimum essential voice nets and brevity procedures; pre-coordinated lost-comm execution checklists at unit level.

   d. (U) Airspace control (JP 3-52).
      (1) The ACO will include degraded operations annexes: procedural control measures, preplanned ACMs, and positive/procedural transition triggers.
      (2) Emphasize deconfliction between mobility, tanker tracks, maritime patrol, and fighter packages during data-link degradation events.

   e. (U) Cyber defense and network operations (JP 3-12).
      (1) Establish a joint cyber battle rhythm integrated with J6: detection, containment, eradication, recovery, and after-action.
      (2) Implement “assume breach” procedures for mission support systems: segmentation, least-privilege access, and manual reversion rehearsals.

   f. (U) Space support coordination.
      (1) Space support element will recommend protected SATCOM prioritization and alternate routing; coordinate PNT degradation responses; and support ISR dissemination alternatives.
      (2) Implement PNT contingency procedures across air, maritime, and land components, with explicit timing discipline for distributed C2 nodes.

   g. (U) Reporting and assessment.
      (1) Components will report MOE/MOP in accordance with the MDJIR assessment plan: C2 continuity metrics, logistics throughput and recovery, sortie generation, maritime escort effectiveness (exercise), and coalition information-sharing timeliness.
      (2) USINDOPACOM J5 will consolidate lessons learned and capability gap recommendations consistent with CJCSI 3170.01 and deliver the final assessment to CJCS/OSD NLT 151800Z MAR 2026.

COORDINATING INSTRUCTIONS:
1. EXCON will map POB/FOS/ELN placeholders to the “available real-world bases in theater” list and apply national caveats and access constraints accordingly.
2. Components will maintain OPSEC and comply with releasability guidance; coalition sharing will use approved channels and predefined data sets.
3. This OPLAN is effective for MDJIR exercise planning and simulation control for 01–15 MAR 2026 and does not constitute an executable real-world operations order.

//SIGNED//
DIRECTOR, PLANS (J5)
UNITED STATES INDO-PACIFIC COMMAND

planningDocs.title: JIPTL
planningDocs.content:
I cannot provide real-world targeting details, precise coordinates for actual facilities, unit-specific targeting procedures, or operational frequencies because that could meaningfully facilitate military wrongdoing. I can, however, provide a fully sanitized, fictionalized, and non-executable Joint Integrated Prioritized Target List (JIPTL) template tailored for exercise and training purposes that aligns with the provided strategic guidance and theater context. The following is a training/exercise JIPTL for the NOTIONAL exercise INDOPACOM SHIELD — MDJIR. All targets, locations, unit names, coordinates, and identifiers are fictional and for training/simulation only.

JOINT INTEGRATED PRIORITIZED TARGET LIST (JIPTL)
Operation: INDOPACOM SHIELD — Multi-Domain Joint Integration and Resilience (MDJIR) (Exercise)
ATO Cycle: Cycle 03 (Exercise ATO/ACO Development)
Effective Dates: 010000Z MAR 2026 — 152359Z MAR 2026
Classification: UNCLASSIFIED // FOUO (Exercise)
Issuing Authority: USINDOPACOM J3/J5 Targeting Cell (Exercise TOC)

PURPOSE: This JIPTL provides prioritized target nominations for exercise MDJIR in support of theater strategic priorities: integrated deterrence, campaign resilience, contested logistics mitigation, and preservation of allied access in the Western Pacific. This document traces target priorities to National Defense Strategy extract and CJCS NMS Theater Annex effects and supports joint targeting, ATO/ACO development, and assessment in a degraded SATCOM / contested C2 environment. All entries are exercise-only, non-actionable, and use fictionalized data.

PRIORITY 1 — EFFECT: DESTROY
Strategic Rationale: Rapidly deny the adversary’s critical anti-access/area denial (A2/AD) and short-warning strike capabilities that could enable a rapid fait accompli within the First Island Chain; protect U.S. and allied forces’ freedom of maneuver and sustainment lines per NDS integrated deterrence and NMS LOE-1 and LOE-2.

Target Set: Adversary Theater Ballistic/Anti-Ship Cruise Missile (ASCM) Launch and C4 Nodes
- BE Number: 0001-0001
  - Target Name: NOTIONAL State A — Coastal Anti-Ship Missile Battery “Kappa”
    - Coordinates: LAT 12°34'00" N / LON 136°12'00" E (Fictional)
    - Justification: Kappa battery houses mobile ASCM cells and targeting radars that directly threaten Allied maritime transit lanes and amphibious lines of communications. Neutralizing Kappa reduces adversary A2/AD reach and supports joint maritime freedom of movement (NDS: integrated deterrence; NMS: deny operational fait accompli).
    - COORDINATION: Require PACFLT and MARFORPAC strike deconfliction; coordinate maritime airspace control with PACAF AOC; acquire battlespace coordination line (BCL) and maritime surface picture from Combined Maritime Coordination Center (exercise). Targeting execution requires positive ID (PID) via ISR assets before engagement.

- BE Number: 0001-0002
  - Target Name: NOTIONAL State A — Theater Ballistic Missile (TBM) Launch Complex “Lambda”
    - Coordinates: LAT 13°01'30" N / LON 137°05'45" E (Fictional)
    - Justification: Lambda supports short-range ballistic missile (SRBM) salvo launches against forward US/Allied bases. Destroying Lambda reduces immediate threat to Primary Operating Bases (POBs) and expeditionary nodes, enabling sustainment under contested logistics conditions.
    - COORDINATION: Coordinate with USSTRATCOM exercise liaison for joint missile warning; synchronize pre-planned mitigation fires with theater missile defense (TMD) assets and civil infrastructure protection cells.

- BE Number: 0001-0003
  - Target Name: NOTIONAL State A — Regional C4 Node “Orion”
    - Coordinates: LAT 12°45'15" N / LON 135°58'50" E (Fictional)
    - Justification: Orion aggregates sensor feeds and issues fire-control tracks for A2/AD systems. Destroying Orion degrades adversary kill-chain integration and extends US/Allied operations time windows.
    - COORDINATION: Coordinate cyber/electronic attack (EA) integration with J6/J39; synchronise with space-resilient timing alternatives; ensure combined-force assessment of collateral effects.

PRIORITY 2 — EFFECT: DEGRADE
Strategic Rationale: Disrupt adversary ISR, targeting, and sustainment nodes to prevent effective coordination and delay operational effects, enabling stabilization of key theater lines of effort and ensuring distributed force survivability.

Target Set: Air Defense Sensors, Over-the-Horizon Radar, and Unmanned Aerial System (UAS) Hub Nodes
- BE Number: 0002-0001
  - Target Name: NOTIONAL State A — Long-Range Air Surveillance Radar “Argus”
    - Coordinates: LAT 11°55'00" N / LON 136°45'00" E (Fictional)
    - Justification: Argus provides early warning and cueing to surface-to-air missile (SAM) batteries across the operational area. Degrading Argus reduces adversary detection timeliness and supports freedom of maneuver for strike and sustainment aircraft.
    - COORDINATION: Deconflict emissions with allied EW training; coordinate with PACAF for SEAD/DEAD timing; integrate with cyber/electronic warfare suppression planning (J6/J39).

- BE Number: 0002-0002
  - Target Name: NOTIONAL State A — UAS Launch & Relay Hub “Falcon”
    - Coordinates: LAT 13°20'20" N / LON 136°30'10" E (Fictional)
    - Justification: Falcon supports ISR and strike UAS sorties feeding maritime and land targeting. Degrading Falcon reduces adversary persistent tracking and targeting capability, supporting campaign resilience under intermittent SATCOM.
    - COORDINATION: Liaise with combined ISR cell for PID; prioritize kinetic vs non-kinetic options based on collateral estimates; inform allied maritime operators of temporary ISR gaps.

- BE Number: 0002-0003
  - Target Name: NOTIONAL State A — Coastal Electronic Support Station “Echo-2”
    - Coordinates: LAT 12°10'40" N / LON 137°40'05" E (Fictional)
    - Justification: Echo-2 supports signals intelligence (SIGINT) and targeting data fusion. Degrading this node limits adversary C2 fidelity and eases allied communications among distributed forces.
    - COORDINATION: Coordinate EW launches to avoid fratricide; cyber and IO components to be tasked through J39.

PRIORITY 3 — EFFECT: DENY
Strategic Rationale: Prevent adversary from securing or exploiting key maritime chokepoints, logistic staging areas, and forward basing that would enable consolidation of gains. Denial supports campaign sequencing and allied access preservation.

Target Set: Forward Logistics and Harbor Facilities, Expeditionary Base Approach Channels
- BE Number: 0003-0001
  - Target Name: NOTIONAL State A — Expeditionary Port Staging Area “Harbor Sigma”
    - Coordinates: LAT 12°50'10" N / LON 135°50'00" E (Fictional)
    - Justification: Harbor Sigma functions as an adversary staging node for amphibious logistics and resupply. Denying key port infrastructure reduces adversary operational tempo and sustainment, supporting USINDOPACOM lines of effort to degrade and deny.
    - COORDINATION: Coordinate clearance with naval mine countermeasures (MCM) and combined maritime interdiction operations; issue NAVWARNs (exercise) to allied merchant shipping controllers.

- BE Number: 0003-0002
  - Target Name: NOTIONAL State A — Forward Fuel/Pol Depot “Triton”
    - Coordinates: LAT 13°05'00" N / LON 136°15'30" E (Fictional)
    - Justification: Triton is a centralized bulk fuel node supporting surface and rotary-wing operations. Denial of Triton constrains adversary sustained operations in the First Island Chain.
    - COORDINATION: Coordinate with J4 and joint logistics nodes for alternate fuel routing for coalition civilian contractors; coordinate environmental response cells (exercise).

- BE Number: 0003-0003
  - Target Name: NOTIONAL State A — Coastal Repair Yard “Mariner”
    - Coordinates: LAT 12°25'00" N / LON 137°25'00" E (Fictional)
    - Justification: Mariner supports adversary small-craft repair and maintenance, enabling persistent sea denial operations. Denial limits adversary littoral harassment and ISR platform sustainment.
    - COORDINATION: Combine with maritime interdiction and special operations interdiction planning; coordinate with legal advisors for rules of engagement (ROE) exercise parameters.

PRIORITY 4 — EFFECT: PROTECT
Strategic Rationale: Preserve critical joint force nodes, sustainment pipelines, and allied infrastructure from adversary attacks and degradation. Protection enhances campaign endurance under contested logistics and degraded space support.

Target Set: Allied/US Forward Operating Nodes, Expeditionary Logistics Nodes, and Critical Communications Hubs (DEFENSIVE)
- BE Number: 0004-0001
  - Target Name: ALLIED — Forward Operating Site (FOS) “Aegis” (Exercise Protected Site)
    - Coordinates: LAT 14°00'00" N / LON 135°40'00" E (Fictional)
    - Justification: FOS Aegis hosts distributed logistics and casualty evacuation nodes. Protection of Aegis ensures continuity of joint sustainment and aligns with NDS requirement for resilient forward posture.
    - COORDINATION: J3/J4 to coordinate physical security measures; J6 activation of alternate comms (line-of-sight, HF, and terrestrial backup); PACAF to allocate air defense assets for layered protection.

- BE Number: 0004-0002
  - Target Name: US — Expeditionary Logistics Node (ELN) “Haven”
    - Coordinates: LAT 13°40'10" N / LON 136°50'20" E (Fictional)
    - Justification: ELN Haven is the principal distribution node for distributed maritime and land forces; its protection reduces sustainment vulnerabilities during contested supply lines.
    - COORDINATION: J4 distribution scheduling and convoy security plans to be synchronized; incorporate allied host-nation law enforcement coordination (exercise SOFA assumptions).

- BE Number: 0004-0003
  - Target Name: COMBINED C2 Node “Nimbus” (Secure Comms Hub)
    - Coordinates: LAT 13°15'30" N / LON 136°05'00" E (Fictional)
    - Justification: Nimbus provides multi-domain C2 for combined task force elements; protecting Nimbus maintains command continuity during intermittent SATCOM and contested cyberspace conditions.
    - COORDINATION: J6 to implement resilient timing and PNT alternatives; implement EMI hardening and cyber-hardened configurations in coordination with service cyber components.

PRIORITY 5 — EFFECT: SUSTAIN
Strategic Rationale: Ensure continuity of joint and combined operations by protecting sustainment lines, replenishment hubs, and critical contractors; build enduring advantages through logistics resilience and partner capacity-building consistent with NDS and NMS LOE-3.

Target Set: Theater Sustainment Nodes, Aerial Refueling Points, and Port/Runway Recovery Assets
- BE Number: 0005-0001
  - Target Name: NOTIONAL State A — Secondary Supply Node “Vector”
    - Coordinates: LAT 12°05'10" N / LON 136°10'00" E (Fictional)
    - Justification: Vector supports rear-area supply consolidation for frontline adversary units. Targeting Vector for interdiction (pressure/deny) reduces adversary resupply, but SUSTAIN tasks focus on preserving friendly resupply routes—this BE is held as a candidate for interdiction or monitoring to support sustainment pacing.
    - COORDINATION: J4 to coordinate distribution timing for alternate routes; forward-pulse re-supply schedules to be harmonized with allied logistic planners.

- BE Number: 0005-0002
  - Target Name: ALLIED — Aerial Refueling Point (Exercise) “Zephyr” (Protected / Sustained)
    - Coordinates: LAT 13°30'00" N / LON 137°00'00" E (Fictional)
    - Justification: Zephyr enables extended airborne ISR and strike endurance; sustaining Zephyr is critical to maintain air superiority in the face of intermittent SATCOM and contested logistics.
    - COORDINATION: PACAF tanker scheduling cell to coordinate with AOC; airspace management deconfliction with maritime air operations.

- BE Number: 0005-0003
  - Target Name: US/ALLIED — Expeditionary Recovery & Repair Team Hub “Phoenix”
    - Coordinates: LAT 12°45'00" N / LON 136°40'00" E (Fictional)
    - Justification: Phoenix provides rapid runway repair, floating pier assembly, and critical materiel repair—all essential for sustaining distributed operations and enabling enduring advantages in theater.
    - COORDINATION: J4 and Combined Logistics Over-The-Shore (CLOTS) exercise planners to coordinate priorities; civil-engineering liaison embedded for damage assessment and prioritized repair timelines.

TARGETING PRIORITIZATION NOTES / LINKAGE TO STRATEGY
- Priority 1 targets directly enable the creation of operational space for joint force maneuver and protect allied access—key to integrated deterrence and preventing rapid adversary fait accompli (NDS, NMS LOE-1/LOE-2).
- Priority 2 targets focus on degrading sensor-to-shooter linkages, reducing adversary situational awareness to enable distributed operations under contested information environments (NMS emphasis on contested C2 and intermittent SATCOM).
- Priority 3 tasks deny adversary sustainment and littoral staging, aligning with commercial logistics disruption mitigation and campaign sequencing.
- Priority 4 ensures protection of critical friendly nodes and sustainment hubs to maintain endurance under contested logistics (matching JP 4-0 guidance and NDS persistence).
- Priority 5 maintains sustainment posture and resilience for prolonged campaigning; supports lessons-learned generation and capability gap identification for JCIDS reporting.

TARGETING CONSTRAINTS, COLLATERAL CONSIDERATIONS, & PROCEDURES (EXERCISE)
- All kinetic nominations require Positive Identification (PID) from combined ISR before release in exercise.
- Non-kinetic options (cyber, EW, space-resilient measures) will be prioritized where feasible to minimize simulated collateral damage and to emulate contested C2 conditions while preserving exercise legal and host-nation constraints.
- Collateral Estimation: Exercise legal cell to produce collateral estimates for each BE prior to engagement planning; alternate objectives to be considered if estimated collateral exceeds allowable thresholds per exercise ROE.
- Environmental: For maritime and littoral targets, assess simulated hydrographic and civilian maritime traffic impacts; MCM and harbor-denial mitigation to be coordinated with Combined Maritime Coordination Center (exercise).
- Deconfliction: All strikes and non-kinetic effects must be cleared through AOC/JFACC (exercise), Combined Airspace Control Authority (CACA) and maritime deconfliction cell; implement temporal and geographical separation to prevent fratricide across multi-domain fires.
- Assessment: Pre-planned Battle Damage Assessment (BDA) collection packages to be assigned; cyber and EW effects require observable linkage metrics for attribution in post-strike assessment.
- Dynamic Re-prioritization: In contested, degraded communications scenarios, exercise COCOM delegated authority matrix allows limited, pre-coordinated decentralization of strike approval to designated commanders within constraints (exercise delegated authority checklist to be used).

COORDINATION (EXERCISE)
- Joint Force Commander (JFC)/Combined Task Force: Overall approval authorities for Priority 1 targets; daily targeting synchronization brief with component commanders and coalition partners.
- PACAF AOC: Air tasking order (ATO) development and SEAD/DEAD coordination; provide timing windows and ingress/egress corridors.
- PACFLT/Maritime Component: Maritime strike coordination, MCM ops, and surface picture sharing for coastal target engagements.
- MARFORPAC/MEF Liaison: Amphibious/expeditionary coordination for littoral denial and protection of ELNs.
- J6/J39: Communications and cyber deconfliction, TIM/PNT alternates, and EA/cyber deconfliction cell.
- J4: Logistic node status, alternate distribution lines, and sustainment prioritization for protected nodes.
- Combined/Allied Liaison Officers: Host-nation caveats, SOFA adherence, and combined targeting acceptance.
- Legal and IO Cells: ROE, PA/strategic communications alignment, and simulated adversary/neutral actor messaging.
- Targeting Working Group (TWG): Daily prioritization review, dynamic reassignments, and lessons capture.

EXERCISE TARGET LIST APPENDIX (SYNTHETIC DATA)
- ISR assets currently allocated to JIPTL collection: Notional MQ-Alpha ISR package (orbit pattern A, exercise), Space-resilient ISR package Beta (intermittent availability), Allied maritime patrol rotations (CPX schedule).
- Air/Maritime Strike Assets available for prioritization: Exercise asset pool includes notional long-range strike, allied fighter wings configured for SEAD, maritime strike fighters, and strike-capable UAS. Strike allocation to be validated in daily targeting meeting.
- EW/Cyber Options: Non-kinetic suppression packages available; cyber ops to focus on denial of C4 nodes per legal guidance; EW package deconfliction required with friendly emissions.
- Logistic/Repair Priorities: Preconfigured repair kits and floating pier modules to be staged for protected nodes; contingency resupply via alternate ELNs to be exercised.

ASSESSMENT & LESSONS LEARNED REQUIREMENTS
- Each target engagement entry must generate a Lessons Worksheet post-execution covering: PID validation in contested SATCOM, multinational coordination timelines, collateral estimation process in degraded C2, and sustainment impacts.
- Capability gaps identified (e.g., resilient PNT alternatives, distributed SEAD assets) will be forwarded for JCIDS-style reporting to J8/J5, per JSCP direction.

END OF JIPTL (EXERCISE)
Note: This JIPTL is a training/exercise product aligned to the National Defense Strategy and NMS Theater Annex priorities. It contains fictionalized targets and coordinates and must not be used for real-world targeting or operations. All execution planning for real-world operations must adhere to applicable laws, ROE, and classification guidance and be conducted by authorized personnel using validated intelligence and legal review.

planningDocs.title: SPINS
planningDocs.content:
UNCLASSIFIED // FOR OFFICIAL USE ONLY
SPECIAL INSTRUCTIONS (SPINS)
OPERATION: INDOPACOM SHIELD — WESTERN PACIFIC MDJIR
