PERIOD: 010000Z MAR 2026 — 152359Z MAR 2026
REFERENCES: NDS Extract 01 MAR 2026; NMS Theater Annex 01 MAR 2026; JSCP MDJIR 01 MAR 2026; CONPLAN/OPLAN MDJIR 01 MAR 2026; JP 5-0, JP 3-0, JP 3-30, JP 3-52, JP 4-0, JP 6-0, JP 3-12

SYNOPSIS: These Special Instructions (SPINS) provide theater-level, exercise-authorized direction for joint/combined forces participating in MDJIR. SPINS are derived from the NDS/NMS/JSCP/CONPLAN/OPLAN authorities and emphasize integrated deterrence, multi-domain resilience, contested logistics readiness, and operations under intermittent space support and degraded communications. This document is for exercise planning and staff training only. Operational details that would be sensitive in real-world employment are sanitized or presented as placeholders to prevent misuse.

1. GENERAL
1.1 Mission and Strategic Alignment. All actions under MDJIR will support theater strategic lines of effort (LOEs): (A) integrated deterrence and combined posture; (B) resilient multi-domain operations under contested logistics and intermittent SATCOM; (C) preservation of freedom of navigation and access across the First Island Chain. Commanders will apply proportionality and discriminate targeting consistent with national policy and ROE provided in the OPLAN annexes.

1.2 Rules of Engagement (ROE) and Positive Identification (PID).
- Use the ROE baseline in Annex ROE-EX (Exercise ROE) for MDJIR. ROE-EX supplements national ROE with exercise-specific escalation control measures.
- PID standard for lethal fires is Positive Identification of hostile intent or hostile act, and PID must meet the “two-source” confirmation rule where available (e.g., cross-cue from ISR and maritime radar, or ISR and tactical EM signature). When two independent sources are not available due to degraded space/comm conditions, commanders will escalate to the next higher authority per escalation procedures in Annex ROE-EX.
- Engagement authority delegation: Unit commanders will not expand engagement authorities beyond those promulgated in the daily Fragmentary Order (FRAGO). Any deviation requires immediate report to the Combined/Joint Air and Maritime Component Commanders (JFACC/JFMCC) and higher.
- Collateral risk assessment: All strike/tactical fires must include man-made structure and civilian casualty risk estimation using the Joint Collateral Damage Estimation (CDE) process; if duration or SIGINT/IMINT gaps preclude accurate CDE, postpone kinetic action or shift to non-kinetic options.

1.3 Civilian Casualty Avoidance and Protection of Civilian Infrastructure.
- Avoid targets located within 2000 meters of critical civilian infrastructure (hospitals, water treatment facilities, civil power grid nodes) unless an imminent threat to forces is verified and no feasible alternative exists.
- Use non-kinetic, low-collateral means where feasible (e.g., electronic attack, cyber effects, precision non-destructive interdiction).
- Immediate reporting: Any incident involving probable civilian casualties requires transmission of a Civilian Harm Mitigation (CHM) Report to the Joint Staff Exercise Inspector and Combined Civilian-Military Liaison (CML) within 60 minutes.

1.4 Sensitive-Site and Noncombatant Evacuation (NEO) Considerations.
- All forces will respect declared Safety/No-Fly and Evacuation Zones around designated diplomatic/consular facilities and UN-recognized humanitarian corridors. Zone definitions and coordinates are promulgated daily in the Exercise Control (EXCON) product EX-DRAG.
- Theater SOF and Host Nation Partner liaison teams coordinate NEO activities under combined guidelines in Annex NEO-EX.

1.5 Degraded/Denied Logistics and Sustainment.
- Force sustainment operates under the Contested Logistics Concept (CLC-EX). Units will pre-register alternate resupply nodes (ELN placeholders) and plan for 48–72 hour autonomous operations without SATCOM or secure strategic reachback.
- Redistribution authorities: Component commanders may authorize local cross-leveling of expendables up to theater-established thresholds; any redistribution exceeding threshold requires J4 concurrence.

2. AIRSPACE CONTROL
2.1 Airspace Control Authority (ACA) and Commander, Air Component Responsibilities.
- The Joint/Combined Airspace Control Authority (ACA) for MDJIR is exercised by the Combined Air Operations Center (CAOC) in its role as the Air Component Coordination Authority; CAOC will publish the daily Airspace Control Order (ACO-EX) and Air Tasking Order (ATO-EX) execution messages.
- All air operations require enroute coordination with the theater Airborne Surveillance and Airborne Warning (ASAW) cell and Deconfliction Cell (DECON), especially when SATCOM/GPS are degraded.

2.2 Altitude Deconfliction and Flight Levels.
- Standard altitude blocks for fixed- and rotary-wing separation are: Low (surface–5,000 ft), Medium (5,001–20,000 ft), High (20,001–FL350), and Very High (above FL350). These blocks are baseline deconfliction; operational FL assignments are in the daily ACO-EX.
- Unmanned Aircraft Systems (UAS) operating in shared corridors will file altitude blocks in increments of no less than 1,000 ft and adhere to assigned lateral corridors in ACO-EX.

2.3 Restricted Operating Zones (ROZ), No-Fly Areas (NFA), and Maritime Airspace Warnings.
- ROZs and NFAs will be promulgated in ACO-EX with exercise-unique identifiers and placeholder coordinates labeled GRID-ROZ-XX. For exercise use, EXCON will map GRID-ROZ-XX to available simulated locations. ROZ status levels: RED (no operations), AMBER (only with ACA coordination), GREEN (normal operations).
- Example exercise ROZ: GRID-ROZ-01 — AMBER; centered at exercise placeholder LZ-A with a 25 nm radius extending surface to FL180. Real-world coordinates are withheld; commanders will reference EXCON mapping for assigned POB/FOS anchors.
- All aircrew must monitor the CAOC common traffic advisory channel and report ingress/egress through ROZ boundaries using standard formatted callsigns and KOCOA (position, altitude, intent, CSAR status).

2.4 Airspace Deconfliction Procedures.
- All air-to-air refueling, ISR, strike, and tanker tracks must file a deconfliction plan to DECON no later than 60 minutes prior to ETD when SATCOM is available; when SATCOM is degraded, file via resilient HF/LOS relay methods per Section 6.
- Immediate deconfliction: If two platforms are observed on converging tracks without prior coordination, both must execute a pre-approved “aired” avoidance vector (standard turn/right 15 degrees and climb/descend 500 ft) and report to DECON within 2 minutes.

3. TANKER OPERATIONS
3.1 Air Refueling (AR) Tracks and Control.
- Tanker operations will be conducted on AR tracks promulgated in the ATO-EX. Tracks are identified by AR-EX identifiers with assigned entry/exit points mapped to exercise placeholders (AR-POINT-A through AR-POINT-H).
- Tanker allocation priorities: (1) Combat Air Patrols (CAP) conducting local air defense over POBs and FOSs; (2) CAS and interdiction strikes supporting assigned LOEs; (3) long-range transits for force redeployment.

3.2 AR Track Procedures and Fuel States.
- Pre-contact fuel states: Receiver aircraft shall request AR no later than bingo+20 minutes to allow AR scheduling when SATCOM is intermittent. Minimum safe fuel states are defined in CFT-EX Annex: Bingo fuel = mission-specific baseline published in daily ATO-EX; emergency fuel = 10% below published bingo baseline.
- Controlled breakout: If planned AR cannot be achieved due to contested environment or tanker attrition, the receiver will divert to alternate fuel plan/ELN or execute pre-briefed single-point recovery procedures from the nearest friendly FOS.

3.3 Tanker Self-Protection and Emission Control (EMCON).
- Tankers will operate under EMCON profiles set in ATO-EX. In high-threat sectors, tankers may require escort or CAP over-watch. When escorted, tanker call signs and escort call signs will be coordinated via CAOC and DECON.
- Tanker critical sustainment: CAOC will maintain a minimum theater tanker on-station readiness equivalent to one sortie package per primary axis to ensure continuity of long-range fighter presence.

4. COMBAT SEARCH AND RESCUE (CSAR)
4.1 CSAR Alert Posture and Authority.
- CSAR posture levels are established in CSAR-EX Annex. Default posture for MDJIR: Alert Condition ALPHA (heightened readiness with staffed CSAR mission sets). Escalation to BRAVO/CHARLIE follows Theater threat assessment.
- Tactical control of CSAR assets during initial response resides with the Combined Rescue Coordination Center (CRCC); on-scene tactical coordination is handed to the closest Airborne CSAR Coordinator (A-SARCOORD).

4.2 CSAR Tasking and Execution Procedures.
- CSAR requests will be processed using the standardized PR/ER (Personnel Recovery/Emergency Recovery) format and forwarded through CAOC/CRCC. In degraded comms, use the pre-briefed two-way relay plan: relay via airborne ASW/ISR platform or partner surface unit.
- Minimum CSAR package composition under contested environment: (a) one rescue helicopter UAS-capable (or manned rotary-wing), (b) dedicated escort fighter or armed UAS, (c) on-scene ISR, (d) airborne tanker as needed for persistence.
- Deconfliction: CSAR ingress corridors will be annotated in ACO-EX as CSAR-ROUTES with time-phased exclusivity windows to avoid fratricide.

4.3 CSAR Frequencies and Authentication.
- Primary authentication and beacon protocols for recovery personnel are promulgated in the PR Authentication Appendix. Exercise communications avoid real-world tactical frequencies; instead use EXCON-authenticated crypto callsigns and placeholders. Personnel will carry both radio and visual authentication means.

5. SPACE SUPPORT
5.1 GPS and PNT Degradation Warnings.
- Due to replicated adversary counterspace effects in MDJIR, intermittent GPS/PNT degradation is an exercise baseline. CAOC Space Liaison (SPACELINK) will disseminate Space Situational Awareness (SSA) and GPS Integrity Advisories (GIA-EX) via the Space Support Message (SSM-EX) at least every 4 hours or immediately upon significant events.
- Units must maintain alternate PNT methods: inertial navigation system (INS), map/ground-reference navigation, celestial navigation where trained, and partner-landmark cross-cueing for maritime units.

5.2 SATCOM Prioritization and Contingency.
- SATCOM capacity is constrained to replicate contested conditions. Prioritization order for SATCOM services: (1) Command & Control (C2) for Combined Force Commander and CAOC, (2) CSAR and lifesaving C2, (3) critical targeting C2, (4) logistic movement orders, (5) routine administrative traffic.
- Backup SATCOM: When primary wideband SATCOM is degraded, units will transition to protected narrowband SATCOM and HF/LOS networks per COMMS Annex. SATCOM tasking and priority adjustments are controlled by J6/SPACELINK.

5.3 Overhead ISR/OPIR Data Feeds.
- OPIR (Overhead Persistent Infrared) simulated feeds will be provided to tactical components on a degraded, time-phased basis to replicate contested collection. Feed allocation is by mission priority with CAOC/Space Liaison controlling tasking. Units that require OPIR data for time-sensitive targeting must submit prioritized requests to CAOC using the Time-Sensitive Target (TST) request process.
- OPIR data dissemination uses the Common Operational Picture (COP)-EX and is subject to intermittent data outages. Units must plan alternative ISR cross-cueing using maritime patrol, AEW, and organic sensors.

6. COMMUNICATIONS
6.1 Communications Guidance and Resilient Architecture.
- Communications resilience guidance follows the Theater Communications Resilience Plan (TCRP-EX). Primary C2 links are theater-provided protected IP and MILSATCOM when available; backups include UHF/VHF LOS mesh, HF single-sideband (SSB) for long-range voice, and Allied Tactical Data Links via partner relays.
- Emplace communications redundancy: Units must be able to operate 48–72 hours without strategic SATCOM reachback using local LOS relays, airborne gateways, and pre-positioned data-bursting schedules.

6.2 Primary and Backup Frequencies/Channels (Sanitized).
- To prevent disclosure of operationally sensitive lane frequencies, SPINS lists frequency bands and modality priorities rather than exact channel numbers:
  - Primary C2: Protected MILSATCOM band (X/Ka-band protected service) for commander-to-component C2.
  - Secondary C2: UHF line-of-sight (satcom fallback) for air control, maritime coordination, and CSAR tasking.
  - Tertiary: HF-SSB for long-range voice between theater HQ and deployed ELNs when SATCOM is denied.
  - Data-link: Tactical Data Link family (TADIL/JTIDS-equivalent) for track reporting; connectors should be configured for echeloned relay via airborne and surface nodes.
  - Voice emergency/guard: Units will monitor pre-briefed exercise guard channels and have an HF emergency watch that supports DSN reachback in degraded environments.
- Authentication/callsigns: Use EXCON-authenticated tactical callsigns and one-time authentication codes for the duration of MDJIR. No real national crypto keys are distributed in exercise products.

6.3 Messaging and Network Procedures.
- Emphasize low-probability-of-intercept/low-probability-of-detection (LPI/LPD) techniques: short-burst data, scheduled windows for non-urgent data uplinks, and pre-arranged store-and-forward relay nodes.
- Email and file exchange: Only use official theater Exchange/Share platforms approved in Annex COMMS-EX. Do not transmit target or force movement details over unsecured commercial SATCOM.

6.4 Electronic Warfare (EW) and Emission Control (EMCON).
- Theater EMCON levels are published in daily ATO-EX. All units will implement EMCON discipline consistent with mission requirements and deconfliction with airspace control measures. EW offensive actions require prior coordination with CAOC and decomposition in the EW Synchronization Matrix.

7. JOINT PROCEDURES AND REPORTING
7.1 Daily Battle Rhythm and Reporting.
- The theater daily battle rhythm: ATO-EX release (T-12 hours), ACO-EX release (T-8 hours), SITREP/COMINT/SSA updates at 4-hour intervals, and commanders’ tactical updates at 2-hour increments during heightened operations.
- Significant Event Reports (SITREP-E) for contested-space events, major fires, or damage to critical infrastructure must be formatted per the SITREP-E template and transmitted within 30 minutes via secure relay.

7.2 Targeting and Time-Sensitive Targets (TST).
- Target nomination and approval follow the joint targeting cycle in Annex TARGET-EX. Time-sensitive targeting requests must include PID and collateral risk assessment; if PID is degraded due to contestation, escalate to higher authority.

7.3 Combined/Allied Coordination.
- Liaison officers (LNOs) from key allies/partners are embedded in CAOC, JFMCC, JFACC, J4, J6, and CRCC. Information sharing adheres to standing bilateral/multilateral intell-sharing agreements; any restrictions are annotated in the Combined Sharing Matrix (CSM-EX).

8. SAFETY, LEGAL, AND ACCOUNTABILITY
8.1 Legal Oversight and Counsel.
- Legal counsel (JAG) advisors remain available in CAOC and component HQs to advise on ROE, targeting legal sufficiency, and civilian harm mitigation. All targeting packages require a legal review signature prior to execution unless exigent circumstances are declared.

8.2 Force Protection and OPSEC.
- Force protection measures are maintained per Annex FP-EX. Operational security (OPSEC) procedures restrict release of operational timelines, unit-level ORBAT, and precise location data in unclassified or partner-shared products without EXCON approval.

9. EXERCISE-SPECIFIC REFERENCES AND PLACEHOLDERS
9.1 Definitions and Placeholders.
- All referenced geographic points (POB, FOS, ELN, AR-POINT, GRID-ROZ) are exercise placeholders to be mapped by EXCON. Real-world coordinates and unit identifiers are not included in this SPINS for safety and security.
9.2 Contacts and Reporting Channels.
- EXCON will publish the daily contact matrix (EX-CONTACT-EX) including CAOC, CRCC, J6, J4, and LNO paging/relay procedures. Use EXCON-authenticated channels for all SPINS changes.

10. AMENDMENTS, WAIVERS, AND VALIDITY
10.1 Amendments. This SPINS will be reviewed and, if required, amended every 24 hours or upon significant change in the operational environment. Amendments will be promulgated by CAOC/EXCON.
10.2 Waivers. Requests for waiver to any SPINS paragraph will be submitted through chain-of-command to CAOC for validation and EXCON approval. Waivers that affect ROE, CSAR posture, or ROZs require higher authority concurrence.
10.3 Validity. These SPINS are valid only for the MDJIR exercise period and are explicitly non-executable for real-world operations.

AUTHORITY: Derived from NDS Extract (01 MAR 2026), NMS Theater Annex (01 MAR 2026), JSCP MDJIR (01 MAR 2026), CONPLAN/OPLAN MDJIR (01 MAR 2026). All participants must ensure actions remain consistent with the guiding authorities.

EXERCISE DISCLAIMER: This SPINS deliberately omits operationally sensitive data (real-world unit identifiers, precise geospatial coordinates, and live tactical frequencies). For real-world operations, component commanders will use classified operational SPINS promulgated through secure channels.

Prepared by: Joint Exercise Plans Cell (J5/J3 CAOC EXCON) — MDJIR SPINS Branch
Date/Time: 01 MAR 2026 / 0600Z
Distribution: CAOC, JFACC, JFMCC, JFLCC, JFSOCC, J4, J6, CRCC, Combined/Allied LNOs, EXCON

planningDocs.title: ACO
planningDocs.content:
HEADQUARTERS, UNITED STATES INDO-PACIFIC COMMAND
AIRSPACE CONTROL ORDER (ACO) 01-EX-INDOPACOM SHIELD
FOR EXERCISE: WESTERN PACIFIC MULTI-DOMAIN JOINT INTEGRATION AND RESILIENCE (MDJIR)
EFFECTIVE: 010000Z MAR 2026 — 152359Z MAR 2026
CLASSIFICATION: UNCLASSIFIED // EXERCISE-ONLY

NOTE: THIS ACO IS AN EXERCISE-ONLY PRODUCT. ALL NAMES/UNIT IDENTIFIERS ARE EXERCISE DESIGNATORS. COORDINATES ARE REPRESENTATIVE GRID CENTERS FOR SIMULATION PURPOSES. THIS DOCUMENT MUST NOT BE USED FOR REAL-WORLD OPERATIONS OR TARGETING.

1. GENERAL
1.1. Purpose. This Airspace Control Order (ACO) provides airspace control measures, restrictions, air refueling tracks, combat air patrol (CAP) stations, transit corridors, and kill box designations to enable safe, deconflicted air operations in support of Operation INDOPACOM SHIELD MDJIR (010000Z–152359Z MAR 2026). Measures support joint integration under contested logistics, degraded SATCOM, and intermittent space support as directed by the NDS Extract, NMS Theater Annex, JSCP MDJIR Tasking, and USINDOPACOM CONPLAN/OPLAN MDJIR.

1.2. Authority. Issued by Commander, USINDOPACOM (CDRUSINDOPACOM) delegating airspace control to Joint Forces Air Component (JFAC) through the Combined/Joint Airspace Control Authority (ACA). The ACA designator for this exercise is ACA-EX. Execution control (EXCON) is delegated to Combined Air Operations Watch (CAOW-EX). All components and participating forces comply with the procedures herein and any subsequent amendments (ACO 01-EX A/B/C etc.).

1.3. Applicability. Applies to all United States, coalition, and permitted partner aircraft, unmanned aerial systems (UAS), and space/stratospheric assets participating in MDJIR. Adversary-representative forces (OPFOR-EX) will operate under separate exercise rules of engagement (ROE) and simulated emissions. Civil aviation will be notified through host-nation NOTAMs and exercise coordination cells. All aircrew must possess current ATO/ACO brief, restrictive area overlays, and authentication tokens (EX-CON AUTHENTICATION).

1.4. Definitions and Conventions.
- Coordinates: Geodetic WGS-84, Latitude/Longitude in degrees and decimal minutes (DD°MM.M’N/S, DD°MM.M’E/W) or military grid reference system (MGRS) where noted.
- Altitudes: Flight Levels (FL) for above transition altitude. Transition altitude = 10,000 ft MSL for exercise. All altitudes expressed as MSL unless otherwise noted.
- Frequencies labeled “EX” are exercise-simulated and are for coordination only.
- Units referenced are exercise designators (e.g., CVBG-EX, 7AF-EX, VMFA(EX), RCN(EX)).

1.5. Communications, Authentication, and Lost-Link Procedures.
- Primary CAOW-EX tactical common: 305.75 MHz VHF Guard (exercise), Secondary 243.0 MHz UHF (exercise).
- CAOW-EX HF backup: 7.300 MHz LSB EX-HF.
- Air Refueling Coordination Cell (ARCC-EX): 215.00 MHz UHF (EX), SATCOM EX-only: 5.0 kHz CPDLC sim.
- Authentication: Two-factor exercise token (Crypto-EX) + daily authentication word issued at 0000Z by CAOW-EX. Lost authentication: land at nearest POB or contact CAOW-EX via EX-HF for re-auth.
- Lost-Link UAS: On lost link, UAS follow predetermined datum point and orbit profile (see Annex A, UAS Lost Link Profiles). All UAS maintain minimum altitude of 500 ft AGL within FOS vicinity unless directed.

1.6. Airspace Management Cells.
- ACA-EX: CAOW-EX, responsible for ATO/ACO execution and dynamic adjustments.
- Airspace Deconfliction Cell (ADC-EX): Coordinates with J3/J5/J2 to resolve conflicts with maritime maneuvers and joint fires.
- Air Refueling Coordination Cell (ARCC-EX): Schedules and monitors all air refueling operations on AR tracks.
- Airspace Safety/Range Control (ASRC-EX): Controls all ROZ activation/deactivation and coordinates with Host Nation ATC (simulated) for civil airspace segregation.

2. RESTRICTED OPERATING ZONES (ROZ)
Notes: ROZ names use exercise sector designators. Coordinates indicate center point; lateral and vertical limits follow each ROZ description. All times Zulu.

2.1. ROZ-ALPHA (POB DEFENSE)
- Purpose: Protect Primary Operating Base (POB) airspace and surface/shore installations; excluded to non-assigned aircraft.
- Center: 16°30.0’N 123°15.0’E (Simulated POB-EX)
- Lateral: 25 NM radius
- Vertical limits: Surface — FL220 (22,000 ft)
- Effective: 010000Z MAR 2026 — 152359Z MAR 2026 (Continuous)
- Procedures: All non-exempt aircraft require positive CAOW-EX clearance and Mode 4/5/ADS-B EX authentication prior to entry. Hostile approach profiles will trigger simulated IOC-EX Firing Warning to POB-EX C2.

2.2. ROZ-BRAVO (FORWARD OPERATING SITE FOS-EX)
- Purpose: Dedicated for expeditionary ISR and strike staging; dynamic reallocation for temporary suppression of simulated adversary C2.
- Center: 19°45.0’N 126°05.0’E (Simulated FOS-EX)
- Lateral: 15 NM radius
- Vertical limits: Surface — FL200
- Effective: Daily 010000Z — 152359Z MAR 2026 with pre-planned active/inactive windows on ATO (see Annex B)
- Procedures: AVPROX buffer: 5 NM from FOS-EX perimeter. UAS/ISTAR permitted with CAOW-EX approval. Tanker ingress/egress restricted to AR tracks A-1/A-2 or dedicated breakout lanes.

2.3. ROZ-CHARLIE (EXPEDITIONARY LOGISTICS NODE ELN-EX)
- Purpose: Secure ELN-EX maritime airspace for sealift/distribution transloads and low-level airdrop practice.
- Center: 18°10.0’N 129°50.0’E (Simulated ELN-EX)
- Lateral: 30 NM radius
- Vertical limits: Surface — FL100
- Effective: 010000Z MAR 2026 — 152359Z MAR 2026, activated for periodic airdrop windows per ATO.
- Procedures: All airdrop ingress routes must be deconflicted with ADC-EX 48 hours prior to window. Mid-air refueling prohibited within 50 NM of ELN-EX.

2.4. ROZ-DELTA (OPFOR-EX SIMULATED A2/AD BUBBLE)
- Purpose: Area of intensified simulated adversary integrated air defense system (IADS) and electronic attack (EA) replication. Non-participating aircraft prohibited.
- Center: 20°30.0’N 124°00.0’E (Generic OPFOR-EX locus)
- Lateral: 40 NM radius
- Vertical limits: Surface — FL460
- Effective: Phased: 010000Z–070000Z MAR 2026 & 120000Z–152359Z MAR 2026 (See ATO)
- Procedures: All participating aircraft must use EMCON EX-ROE1/EW profiles. Passive navigation and low-probability of intercept (LPI) comms recommended. CAOW-EX will publish permitted ingress and egress corridors. Weapons release against targets in ROZ-DELTA is simulated only; real-world weapons employment not permitted within exercise ROZ.

3. AIR REFUELING TRACKS (AR TRACKS)
General: AR tracks published to support sustained fighter/ISR presence in the First Island Chain and outer island tasks. Tankers operate under ARCC-EX control and must coordinate with CAOW-EX for scheduling and dynamic re-tasking. All tracks are one-way orbits unless specified.

3.1. AR-TRACK A-1 (POB-EX Outer Orbit)
- Track centerline: 17°45.0’N 123°45.0’E
- Lateral: 20 NM corridor width (10 NM either side)
- Altitudes: FL200 — FL280
- Speed: 220 KIAS (tanker orbit speed)
- Entry/Exit: Prescribed ingress lanes to the south and egress to north. Minimum rendezvous separation 5 NM laterally/1,000 ft vertical unless directed. Tanker types: TK-EX/1 (simulated KC-135EX), TK-EX/2 (simulated KC-46EX).
- Frequencies: ARCC-EX Primary 215.00 MHz UHF (EX), Secondary 306.50 MHz VHF (EX)
- Control: ARCC-EX controls all spares and on-call tankers. Fighters will authenticate per ARCC-EX procedure before offload.

3.2. AR-TRACK A-2 (FORWARD AR SUPPORT FOR FOS-EX)
- Track centerline: 19°30.0’N 126°20.0’E
- Lateral: 12 NM corridor
- Altitudes: FL160 — FL220
- Speed: 220 KIAS
- Effective: 010300Z — 152300Z MAR 2026 (intermittent windows per ATO)
- Tanker types: TANKER-EX/3 (simulated boom/drogue mixed)
- Procedures: Tankers may be re-tasked to AR-TRACK A-2 with 30-minute notice. Fighters must plan fuel states to meet min-time-on-station requirements when scheduled.

3.3. AR-TRACK B-1 (Long-Range Outer Track)
- Track centerline: 22°00.0’N 130°00.0’E (outer island screen)
- Lateral: 25 NM corridor
- Altitudes: FL260 — FL340
- Speed: 230 KIAS
- Frequencies: ARCC-EX Primary 215.75 MHz UHF (EX)
- Note: AR-TRACK B-1 supports long-range escort missions. All tankers on B-1 must carry reserve fuel for alternate recovery instructions given degraded tanker basing.

4. CAP STATIONS (COMBAT AIR PATROL)
CAP stations provide air superiority, local defense, and quick reaction intercept capabilities. All CAP aircraft operate under JFACC/CAOC-EX control.

4.1. CAP-STN-1 (POB-EX Inner CAP)
- Center: 16°40.0’N 123°25.0’E
- Holding pattern: 15 NM radius
- Altitudes: FL250 — FL320
- Alert unit: CVBG-EX FtrSqn-EX (two four-ship rotations) — simulated F/A-EX platforms
- Procedures: On scramble, CAP-STN-1 aircraft must be airborne within 10 minutes; intercept handoff to CAP-STN-2 if target transits northward. Weapons status: Simulated air-to-air live training rounds authorized only in range-controlled airspace (see Annex C).

4.2. CAP-STN-2 (FOS-EX Forward CAP)
- Center: 19°45.0’N 126°05.0’E
- Holding pattern: 12 NM radius
- Altitudes: FL180 — FL250
- Alert unit: 7AF-EX Air Superiority Detachment (rotational)
- Procedures: CAP-STN-2 provides short-notice intercept and overwatch for FOS-EX operations. Rules: minimum intercept separation 3 NM lateral/500 ft vertical; handover to local SHADE when over water transit corridor.

4.3. CAP-STN-3 (ELN-EX Maritime CAP)
- Center: 18°05.0’N 129°45.0’E
- Holding pattern: 20 NM radius
- Altitudes: FL120 — FL200
- Alert unit: VMFA(EX) (Marines air unit, simulated)
- Procedures: CAP-STN-3 provides low-altitude intercept capability and supports anti-surface search. Night operations require NVG-certified crews or synthetic vision; coordinate NVG lighting with ASRC-EX.

5. TRANSIT CORRIDORS
Transit corridors facilitate safe movement of aircraft through contested domains and support deconfliction with maritime operations and friendly surface units.

5.1. TRANS-CORRIDOR T-1 (FIRST ISLAND CHAIN ALONG-MAIN AXIS)
- Route: From POB-EX approach (16°30.0’N 123°15.0’E) northbound to 21°00.0’N 125°00.0’E.
- Lateral: 30 NM wide (15 NM either side of centerline)
- Altitudes: FL060 — FL180 (transit altitudes encouraged below FL100 to minimize detection in simulated scenario; higher altitudes authorized when air refueling or CAP integration required)
- Procedures: All aircraft transiting T-1 must file corridor entry time and track plan on the ATO and maintain continuous comms with CAOW-EX or relay via designated TACAN/RADAR uplinks. Military formation sizes limited to 8 aircraft without prior coordination.

5.2. TRANS-CORRIDOR T-2 (OUTER ISLAND ROUTE)
- Route: East-west corridor between 20°00.0’N 128°00.0’E and 20°00.0’N 122°00.0’E
- Lateral: 20 NM corridor
- Altitudes: FL100 — FL300
- Procedures: Used for logistics movement and for transiting tankers to AR-TRACK B-1. Civil traffic avoidance: CAOW-EX to coordinate with host nation ATC for simulated civil overlay.

5.3. TRANS-CORRIDOR T-3 (LOW-LEVEL LOG ROUTE)
- Route: Coastal low-level lane from ELN-EX to FOS-EX
- Lateral: 10 NM
- Altitudes: Surface — 5,000 ft AGL (low-level)
- Procedures: Restricted to rotary and CAS assets conducting resupply, medevac, and low-level insertion. Electronic emissions limited per ATO EMCON status. Minimum separation from surface shipping 3 NM lateral.

6. KILL BOXES
Kill boxes designate three-dimensional areas where joint fires may be executed with deconfliction measures to expedite engagements. All engagements are simulated under exercise rules unless otherwise annotated as live fire in range control annexes.

General Kill Box Procedures:
- Engagement authority within each kill box is delegated to the Joint Fires Element (JFE-EX) under JFACC-EX with prescribed weapons release procedures.
- Aircrews must receive positive clearance from JFE-EX and authentication code for each engagement. Unplanned engagement against emergent threats requires contact with CAOW-EX; if comms denied, default to self-defense ROE.
- Effects: The following kill boxes are authorized for air-to-surface, surface-to-surface, and anti-surface seaborne fires as designated. All munitions employment within the kill box must abide by simulated collateral constraints in Annex D and be corroborated by joint DCA/EWR assets.

6.1. KILL BOX K-RED-1 (OFFENSIVE AIR-TO-SURFACE)
- Designation: K-RED-1
- Coordinates (box corners): NW 21°30.0’N 125°30.0’E; NE 21°30.0’N 126°30.0’E; SE 20°30.0’N 126°30.0’E; SW 20°30.0’N 125°30.0’E
- Altitudinal limits: Surface — FL460
- Permitted Effects: Air-to-surface strikes (SIM), UAS attack sorties (SIM), cruise missile simulated launches (SIM).
- Engagement Rules: Positive two-source targeting (ISR asset + JTAC-EX or JFE-EX) required for high-value target simulation. Weapons release authority: JFACC-EX delegated to On-Scene Commander only when JTAC-EX confirms target and Centre of Gravity (COG) assessment completed. SEAD/DEAD allowed but must coordinate with EW cell and not exceed simulated frequency occupancy.

6.2. KILL BOX K-BLUE-2 (ANTI-SURFACE)
- Designation: K-BLUE-2
- Coordinates (box corners): NW 18°50.0’N 130°10.0’E; NE 18°50.0’N 131°00.0’E; SE 17°50.0’N 131°00.0’E; SW 17°50.0’N 130°10.0’E
- Altitudinal limits: Surface — FL220
- Permitted Effects: Anti-surface warfare simulated engagements (air-launched and surface-launched), maritime strike coordination.
- Engagement Rules: Require clearance from Maritime Fires Element (MFE-EX) and positive identification of target vessel by two separate sensors (radar + visual/EO/IR). No simulated missiles to be expended within 10 NM of ELN-EX unless under specific live-fire authorization by ASRC-EX.

6.3. KILL BOX K-GREEN-3 (SUPPRESSION OF IADS / SEAD)
- Designation: K-GREEN-3
- Coordinates: Center 20°10.0’N 124°00.0’E with 30 NM radius
- Altitudinal limits: Surface — FL460
- Permitted Effects: SEAD/DEAD suppression operations, EW sorties, jamming trial lanes.
- Engagement Rules: All SEAD/DEAD must coordinate with EW Control Authority (EWCA-EX). Jamming windows will be distributed in 30-minute blocks; CAOW-EX will publish jam codes. Friendly airframes will configure ECCM as defined in the ATO.

6.4. KILL BOX K-YELLOW-4 (JOINT-FORCES INTEGRATED STRIKE)
- Designation: K-YELLOW-4 (Dynamic)
- Coordinates: Variable; activated/deactivated by JFACC-EX with 30-minute notice to CAOW-EX and ADC-EX.
- Altitudinal limits: As promulgated in activation message.
- Permitted Effects: Multi-domain integrated strike with coordinated maritime, air, cyber, and space-simulated effects.
- Engagement Rules: Requires pre-coordination in the Mission Planning Cell (MPC-EX), positive fire support coordination measures, and deconfliction brief 60 minutes prior to activation. Cyber-kinetic sequencing must confirm simulated space SATCOM windows to avoid inadvertent fratricide of friendly comms.

7. SPECIAL PROCEDURES AND SAFETY
7.1. DCA and Friendly Air Defense. Air Defense Identification Zone (ADIZ-EX) procedures will be strictly enforced around POB-EX and FOS-EX. All participants must maintain updated Identification Friend or Foe (IFF) EX codes. Any aircraft failing to comply will be treated as OPFOR-EX after exercise-prescribed warnings.

7.2. Electronic Warfare and EMCON. EMCON profiles will be set in ATO. EW operations within ROZ-DELTA and K-GREEN-3 require CAOW-EX coordination and publication of permitted emitter windows. Passive navigation and LPI comms strongly encouraged. GPS-denial simulation will be active in ROZ-DELTA and selected corridors; alternate navigation (inertial, TACAN) must be pre-briefed.

7.3. Space/Stratospheric Asset Deconfliction. Simulated satellite outages will be managed by CAOW-EX. High-altitude ISR or stratospheric platforms must coordinate to avoid conflicts with civilian transits. Any would-be real-world overflight of international civil airspace remains outside exercise control and will be coordinated through civil authorities.

7.4. Ordnance and Munitions. All weapons employment during the exercise will be simulated unless otherwise directed by ASRC-EX via a Live Fire Authorization Note. Live munitions use must be scheduled through ASRC-EX and range control and will adhere to host-nation and international safety standards.

7.5. Air-to-Air Refueling (AAR) Emergencies. Emergency AAR procedures (low fuel state declarations) shall follow the Ladder-of-Preferences in Annex E. Primary emergency recovery fields: nearest POB-EX or designated ALT-EX bases. CAOW-EX to issue emergency reallocation with highest priority.

8. REPORTING, AMENDMENTS, AND COORDINATION
8.1. ACO Amendments. CAOW-EX will publish ACO amendments (01-EX A, B, C…) to reflect dynamic ROZ activation, kill box changes, and AR track updates. Amendments become effective upon broadcast and acknowledgment by primary units.

8.2. Incident and Safety Reporting. All incidents (near misses, losses, unexpected weapons simulation impacts, or simulated fratricide) must be reported immediately to CAOW-EX and ADC-EX and documented in the Exercise Safety Report (ESR) within 12 hours.

8.3. RFI and Deconfliction. Units requiring corridor/ROZ exemptions must submit RFI to ADC-EX no less than 48 hours prior to operation. Time-critical requests accepted under commander’s discretion but require CAOW-EX concurrence.

9. ANNEXES (Reference for detailed procedures)
- Annex A: UAS/Unmanned Systems Lost-Link Profiles and Minimum Safe Altitudes
- Annex B: ROZ Activation Calendar and Airdrop Windows
- Annex C: Live-Fire Range Control and Simulated Munitions Constraints
- Annex D: Collateral Damage Estimation (CDE) Constraints for Simulated Strikes
- Annex E: Emergency Recovery Fields and Low-Fuel Ladder-of-Preferences
- Annex F: Authentication Word Release Schedule and COMSEC Measures
- Annex G: Airspace Deconfliction Matrix (Cross-Component)

10. AUTHENTICATION
Issued by: ACA-EX / JFACC-EX
Signature/Authentication: CAOW-EX Control Code (exercise token) — EX-AUTH: “SILVER-ANCHOR-030126”
Date/Time: 010000Z MAR 2026

Distribution: All participating USINDOPACOM components, coalition/partner EX teams, host-nation exercise control, CAOC-EX, ARCC-EX, ASRC-EX, JFE-EX, EWCA-EX, Maritime Fires Element (MFE-EX), and Exercise Safety Office.

End of ACO 01-EX-INDOPACOM SHIELD.

planningDocs.title: Master Air Attack Plan (MAAP)
planningDocs.content:
MASTER AIR ATTACK PLAN (MAAP)
Operation: INDOPACOM SHIELD — Multi-Domain Joint Integration and Resilience (MDJIR) (EXERCISE / NOTIONAL)
Theater: Western Pacific (INDOPACOM) — Exercise-Only, Non-Executable
MAAP Coverage: Day 1 through Day 15 (01–15 MAR 2026), with daily ATO development driven by this MAAP and updated by AOD/PRF/ISR assessment each ATO cycle.
Supported Commander: JFC (Exercise)
Supporting Commander: JFACC (Exercise AOC)

NOTE ON SANITIZATION: This MAAP is intentionally generalized and non-executable. It uses notional operating locations (POB/FOS/Carrier), notional track/station names, and deliberately avoids real-world installation targeting, coordinates, frequencies, or unit-specific tactics. Sortie numbers are for staff training and simulation only.

----------------------------------------------------------------------
1. COMMANDER’S GUIDANCE
----------------------------------------------------------------------

1.1 Operational Emphasis (Exercise Effects)
a. Priority of effort is to demonstrate joint force resilience and decision advantage under contested C2: intermittent SATCOM, degraded PNT, datalink interference, and cyber pressure on logistics and unclassified networks.
b. Air operations will focus on generating repeatable effects aligned to the exercise JIPTL priorities:
   (1) P1: Rapidly neutralize adversary A2/AD strike and IADS “gates” to open/hold maneuver corridors.
   (2) P2: Degrade adversary theater ISR/C2 to reduce their targeting cycle and force dithering.
   (3) P3: Suppress/attrit adversary air and maritime strike capacity (airfields, maritime surface action groups as simulated).
   (4) P4: Disrupt adversary operational sustainment and deployment tempo (logistics nodes, fuel/munitions distribution as simulated).
   (5) P5: Protect the force and preserve coalition access: DCA, maritime protection, CSAR posture, and information operations synchronization (exercise injects).

1.2 Desired End State (Exercise)
a. JFACC maintains continuous, resilient C2 to generate ATOs despite comm degradation.
b. Air component establishes and sustains:
   (1) Two notional air maneuver corridors through the First Island Chain equivalent (exercise geometry),
   (2) A persistent DCA umbrella over designated defended assets (DAs),
   (3) A repeatable kill-chain for time-sensitive targets (TSTs) under degraded PNT/SATCOM, demonstrated in Phase 3.

1.3 Targeting and Fires Restrictions (Exercise / Training)
a. No real-world lethal execution is authorized; all effects are simulated/adjudicated.
b. No strikes against real-world civilian infrastructure; “dual-use” targets are represented only as simulated target sets with EXCON-approved aimpoints.
c. Collateral damage constraints are modeled: planners must select aimpoints and fuzing concepts that would keep collateral effects within “LOW” modeled thresholds unless EXCON directs otherwise.
d. No-cyber impact boundaries: cyber effects will be simulated and restricted to exercise networks/constructs; no real-world systems.

1.4 Risk Tolerance
a. Operational risk to mission accomplishment: MODERATE. Accept localized sortie shortfalls if required to preserve C2 integrity, force protection, and safety-of-flight in degraded nav.
b. Risk to force (exercise attrition model): LOW to MODERATE. Do not trade away 5th-gen penetration capacity early; prioritize survivability and electronic protection.
c. Logistics risk: MODERATE. Expect contested fuel and weapons movement; plan for “lean” forward stocks and prioritize high-payoff effects over volume.

1.5 C2 and Communications Intent (Degraded Environment)
a. Primary: mission-type orders and commander’s intent; minimize real-time micromanagement.
b. Data-link denial is expected; packages must be able to execute with:
   (1) pre-briefed ROZ/route decision points,
   (2) inertial nav and timing back-ups,
   (3) comm-out rejoin and divert procedures.
c. Airborne C2 will be treated as a contested asset; maintain emission control (EMCON) discipline per daily SPINS and EXCON adjudication.

----------------------------------------------------------------------
2. SORTIE ALLOCATION MATRIX
----------------------------------------------------------------------

2.1 Available Combat Air/ISR Capacity (Notional Force for Exercise)
a. 5th Gen Fighter Squadron (FTR-5G): 24 aircraft at POB-1
   - Sustainable sortie generation rate (SGR): 1.15 sorties/aircraft/day
   - Planned daily sorties: 28
b. 4th Gen Fighter Squadron (FTR-4G): 18 aircraft at POB-2
   - SGR: 1.30 sorties/aircraft/day
   - Planned daily sorties: 23
c. Carrier Air Wing Strike Fighters (CV STRIKE): 36 aircraft at CARRIER-1
   - SGR: 1.35 sorties/aircraft/day
   - Planned daily sorties: 49
d. SIGINT/ISR: 4 large ISR aircraft at POB-1 (strategic/tactical SIGINT)
   - SGR: 0.75 sorties/aircraft/day
   - Planned daily sorties: 3
e. Enabler assumptions (exercise-controlled, not tied to real units):
   - Tankers: 10–14 sorties/day (varies by phase and weather)
   - Airborne C2 (AWACS/E-7 class): 4 sorties/day (2 orbits sustained)
   - Rescue alert (rotary/fixed-wing equivalent): 2–4 sorties/day (posture dependent)
   - Maritime surface/undersea fires (simulated): available for coordinated effects; not counted as “air sorties”

2.2 Total Planned Daily Sortie Capacity (Phase-Dependent)
a. Core fighter/ISR planned daily sorties (steady-state): 28 + 23 + 49 + 3 = 103 sorties/day
b. Enablers planned daily sorties: typically 16–22 sorties/day
c. Total ATO-visible sorties/day (all categories): 119–125 sorties/day (Phase 1 peak), 112–118 (Phase 2), 105–112 (Phase 3 with more dynamic retasking and weather/maintenance variability)

2.3 JIPTL Priority to Mission-Type Mapping (Baseline Daily Allocation)
The following matrix is the MAAP baseline. The AOD may shift ±10–15% day-to-day based on BDA, threat changes, weather, and logistics injects.

P1 — EFFECT: DESTROY (A2/AD strike complexes; IADS “gates”; long-range fires enablers)
Mission types required:
- SEAD/DEAD (pre-planned), OCA strike, escort, standoff maritime strike (simulated), EW support, ISR confirmation
Platforms assigned (notional):
- FTR-5G: penetration strike/escort (primary)
- CV STRIKE: SEAD/strike/escort (primary)
- FTR-4G: standoff SEAD support, sweep (secondary)
- SIGINT/ISR: threat emitter mapping, post-strike confirmation (as tasked)
Baseline sorties/day by phase:
- Phase 1 (Days 1–3): 34 sorties/day (fighter) + 1 ISR
  • FTR-5G: 12
  • CV STRIKE: 18
  • FTR-4G: 4
  • SIGINT/ISR: 1 (focused)
- Phase 2 (Days 4–7): 22 sorties/day (fighter) + 1 ISR
  • FTR-5G: 8
  • CV STRIKE: 12
  • FTR-4G: 2
  • SIGINT/ISR: 1
- Phase 3 (Days 8+): 14 sorties/day (fighter) + 0–1 ISR (as needed)
  • FTR-5G: 6
  • CV STRIKE: 6
  • FTR-4G: 2
  • SIGINT/ISR: 0–1

P2 — EFFECT: DEGRADE / DENY (Theater ISR/C2; targeting network; data relay; cyber/EW nodes — simulated)
Mission types required:
- Non-kinetic effects (exercise EW/cyber coordination), strike against nodes (simulated), escort, ISR localization, airborne collection
Platforms assigned:
- SIGINT/ISR: primary (collection, cueing, pattern-of-life)
- FTR-5G: penetration “node strikes,” escort
- CV STRIKE: strike/escort
- FTR-4G: supplemental sweep, defensive counter-air to protect enablers
Baseline sorties/day by phase:
- Phase 1: 14 sorties/day (fighter) + 2 ISR
  • FTR-5G: 5
  • CV STRIKE: 7
  • FTR-4G: 2
  • SIGINT/ISR: 2
- Phase 2: 18 sorties/day (fighter) + 2 ISR
  • FTR-5G: 6
  • CV STRIKE: 10
  • FTR-4G: 2
  • SIGINT/ISR: 2
- Phase 3: 16 sorties/day (fighter) + 2–3 ISR (TST cueing emphasis)
  • FTR-5G: 5
  • CV STRIKE: 9
  • FTR-4G: 2
  • SIGINT/ISR: 2–3

2.4 Daily Totals vs. Capacity (Baseline)
Phase 1 (Days 1–3) baseline fighter sorties:
- P1 34 + P2 14 + P3 20 + P4 8 + P5 31 = 107 fighter sorties/day
Planned fighter capacity: 28 + 23 + 49 = 100 fighter sorties/day
Delta: -7 (shortfall) mitigations:
- Reduce P5 by 5 (accept moderate risk; rely on layered ship-based IAMD injects)
- Reduce P3 by 2 (delay non-critical neutralization targets to Day 2/3)
Adjusted Phase 1 planned: 100 fighter sorties/day + 3 ISR/day + 18–22 enablers/day

Phase 2 (Days 4–7) baseline fighter sorties:
- P1 22 + P2 18 + P3 26 + P4 14 + P5 24 = 104 fighter sorties/day
Capacity: 100 fighter sorties/day
Delta: -4 mitigations:
- Reduce P3 by 2 (retain ability to surge)
- Reduce P5 by 2 (accept moderate risk; increase alert posture at DAs)
Adjusted Phase 2 planned: 100 fighter sorties/day + 3 ISR/day + 16–20 enablers/day

Phase 3 (Days 8+) baseline fighter sorties:

Capacity: 100 fighter sorties/day
Surplus: +8 held as flex for dynamic targeting, weather re-attacks, or maintenance recovery; allocate by AOD to TST windows.

2.5 Notional Weapon/Loadout Policy (Exercise-Only)
a. Emphasize “effects-based” loads: fewer aimpoints per sortie when PNT is degraded and comm re-attacks are uncertain.
b. Preserve limited high-end munitions inventory (simulated) for P1/P2 and Phase 3 TST; push P4 with medium confidence aimpoints only when ISR cueing is strong.
c. When GPS quality is assessed “DEGRADED,” shift to:
   (1) preplanned visual/INS-aided deliveries (simulated),
   (2) standoff effects (simulated),
   (3) non-kinetic suppression where available (exercise).

----------------------------------------------------------------------
3. PHASE EMPLOYMENT CONCEPT
----------------------------------------------------------------------

3.1 Phase 1 (Days 1–3): Initial Strikes, SEAD, DCA Establishment
Purpose: Create operational access (simulated), blunt adversary first salvo potential, and establish a stable DCA/HVAA protection architecture while demonstrating C2 resilience.

Key tasks by day:
Day 1:
- P1: Execute “Gate Opener” packages against the two highest-payoff A2/AD strike complexes and IADS sector operations nodes (simulated target sets). Objective is to reduce modeled threat rings and open Corridor A.
- P5: Establish two continuous BARCAPs over primary defended assets; prioritize HVAA escort for tankers and airborne C2.
- P2: ISR-led mapping of emitter activity; initiate degradation of theater ISR/C2 via simulated node strikes and non-kinetic actions.
Day 2:
- P1: Expand SEAD/DEAD to adjacent IADS nodes to hold Corridor A and open Corridor B (second maneuver corridor).
- P3: Begin OCA sweeps and simulated airfield suppression to reduce adversary sortie generation and maritime strike cueing.
- P2: Continue suppression of data relay and targeting network; focus on shortening adversary kill-chain.
Day 3:
- Consolidate: Re-attack surviving/relocated P1 elements as cued by ISR; transition from “breach” to “hold” operations.
- Increase P3/P4 only if P1 effects are assessed sufficient (MOE threshold in Section 6).

Rules of employment (Phase 1):
- Do not expend more than 60% of simulated “high-end” stocks before Day 4 unless EXCON inject indicates imminent major adversary strike.
- Maintain at least one DCA orbit at all times; no “all-in” strike day.

3.2 Phase 2 (Days 4–7): Sustained Operations, Deep Strike
Purpose: Sustain pressure on adversary operational system while maintaining access and protecting the force; shift weight from “opening” to sustained degradation and interdiction.

Operational approach:
- P1: Maintain “Suppression Belt” along Corridors A/B; prioritize mobile long-range strike systems and reconstituting IADS nodes (simulated).
- P2: Intensify attacks on command and sensor fusion nodes (simulated), using ISR to identify redundancy and force “fallback to voice” conditions in adversary construct.
- P3: Expand maritime strike and counter-air to attrit adversary strike packages before they can mass; use carrier-based aviation for flexible presence.
- P4: Begin deliberate interdiction of key sustainment lines; aim to create cascading delays (modeled) in fuel and weapons distribution.
- P5: Reduce routine CAP density slightly, but maintain surge-ready alert and HVAA escort.

Daily rhythm (Phase 2):
- Two major strike windows/day (one day, one night cycle), with one smaller dynamic window for TST/SCAR.
- ISR aircraft fly a “long look” every day to maintain continuity of electronic order of battle and cue dynamic re-attacks.

3.3 Phase 3 (Days 8+): Exploitation, Dynamic Targeting
Purpose: Demonstrate ability to exploit advantage, prosecute dynamic targets, and preserve force while sustaining contested C2.

Operational approach:
- Shift from fixed target emphasis to dynamic targeting, armed ISR, and SCAR to prosecute time-sensitive targets (mobile launchers, maritime movers, pop-up IADS nodes—simulated).
- Use sortie surplus (Section 2.4) as a “flex pool” for weather re-attacks, divert-tasked interdiction, and surge DCA in response to adversary raid injects.
- Emphasize low signature and comm discipline. When SATCOM is denied, execute with preplanned decision points and on-scene commander intent.

Phase 3 success condition:
- Demonstrated completion of at least one full “degraded kill-chain” per day: detect → identify → task → engage → assess under simulated comm/PNT degradation.

----------------------------------------------------------------------
4. SPACE SUPPORT REQUIREMENTS (EXERCISE)
----------------------------------------------------------------------

4.1 PNT (GPS / Multi-Constellation) Support Concept
a. Planning assumption: intermittent jamming/spoofing creates two daily “PNT stress windows” and localized outages near high-value target sets (simulated).
b. Precision engagement windows (planning guidance):
- Primary “High-Confidence PNT” windows: 0300Z–0700Z and 1500Z–1900Z (exercise-controlled). Schedule the most PNT-sensitive P1/P2 strikes inside these windows when feasible.
- “Degraded PNT” windows: 0700Z–1100Z and 1900Z–2300Z. Use for DCA, maritime presence, and less PNT-sensitive interdiction where INS/visual backup is acceptable (simulated).
c. Mitigations:
- Require preplanned aimpoint mensuration and inertial navigation cross-check.
- Include timing gates based on TOT windows rather than continuous updates.
- Maintain a minimum of two independent timing sources for package lead (exercise procedure).

4.2 SATCOM Allocation by Mission Type (Notional)
a. Protected SATCOM (EHF class) priorities:
(1) Airborne C2 nodes and AOC reachback continuity
(2) HVAA coordination for tankers and ISR aircraft
(3) Package-level retasking for P1/P2 when datalinks are degraded
b. Tactical SATCOM (UHF/MUOS class) priorities:
(1) Fighter package coordination when LOS is blocked
(2) CSAR alert coordination and survivor communications (exercise)
(3) Maritime coordination for dynamic targeting
c. Wideband SATCOM priorities:
(1) ISR product dissemination to the AOC (when available)
(2) ATO/ACO/SPINS distribution to forward nodes
d. Contested SATCOM mitigation:
- Assume one wideband path degraded at any time; plan alternate routing via protected SATCOM for critical C2 messages and use store-and-forward for non-critical products.
- Daily SPINS will designate “comms minimums” and authentication procedures for comm restoration.

4.3 ISR / OPIR Support Schedule (Exercise)
a. OPIR (launch detect) support is assumed continuous but with reporting delays during contested comm windows.
b. Daily ISR deck (baseline):
- 1 SIGINT/ISR sortie during the primary strike window (0300Z–0700Z) focused on P1/P2 cueing and emitter mapping.
- 1 SIGINT/ISR sortie during the secondary window (1500Z–1900Z) focused on maritime/air track correlation and post-strike assessment.
- 1 SIGINT/ISR sortie “swing” scheduled by AOD for highest-need: either dynamic targeting in Phase 3 or re-attack cueing in Phase 2.
c. Collection priorities:
(1) Emitter geolocation and identification to support SEAD/DEAD adjudication
(2) Maritime mover detection and classification (simulated)
(3) Post-strike indications for BDA modeling (communications shifts, emitter silence, rerouting)

----------------------------------------------------------------------
5. FLOW PLAN
----------------------------------------------------------------------

5.1 Airspace and Routing Construct (Notional)
a. Two primary maneuver corridors (Corridor A and Corridor B) defined in the ACO with time-phased activation; corridors are opened by Phase 1 P1 effects and held by continuous suppression.
b. Package assembly areas:
- ASSEMBLY WEST (for carrier-based packages)
- ASSEMBLY EAST (for land-based packages)
c. ROZs (restricted operating zones) will be published daily; dynamic ROZ establishment is authorized via airborne C2 if comm allows.

5.2 Tanker Flow and Tracks (Notional, No Coordinates)
a. Tanker tracks (all notional; geometry published in ACO as track boxes):
- TRACK ALPHA (forward, high-demand): supports penetration/escort and time-on-station for CAPs
- TRACK BRAVO (mid): supports strike packages prior to corridor entry
- TRACK CHARLIE (rear): recovery/emergency/divert support
b. Tanker sortie allocation by 6-hour period (Phase 1 peak / Phase 2 steady / Phase 3 flexible):
Time Block 0000Z–0600Z:
- Phase 1: 4 tanker sorties (2 ALPHA, 1 BRAVO, 1 CHARLIE)
- Phase 2: 3 tanker sorties (1 ALPHA, 1 BRAVO, 1 CHARLIE)
- Phase 3: 2–3 tanker sorties (0–1 ALPHA depending on TST; 1 BRAVO; 1 CHARLIE)
Time Block 0600Z–1200Z:
- Phase 1: 3 tanker sorties (1 ALPHA, 1 BRAVO, 1 CHARLIE)
- Phase 2: 3 tanker sorties (1 ALPHA, 1 BRAVO, 1 CHARLIE)
- Phase 3: 2 tanker sorties (1 BRAVO, 1 CHARLIE)
Time Block 1200Z–1800Z:
- Phase 1: 4 tanker sorties (2 ALPHA, 1 BRAVO, 1 CHARLIE)
- Phase 2: 4 tanker sorties (1–2 ALPHA, 1 BRAVO, 1 CHARLIE)
- Phase 3: 3 tanker sorties (1 ALPHA for dynamic window, 1 BRAVO, 1 CHARLIE)
Time Block 1800Z–2400Z:
- Phase 1: 3 tanker sorties (1 ALPHA, 1 BRAVO, 1 CHARLIE)
- Phase 2: 3 tanker sorties (1 ALPHA, 1 BRAVO, 1 CHARLIE)
- Phase 3: 2 tanker sorties (1 BRAVO, 1 CHARLIE)
c. Tanker demand management:
- Strike packages receive refuel priority during corridor transit windows.
- DCA CAPs are planned with one scheduled top-off per 2.5–3.0 hours.
- In “tanker short” conditions, reduce P4 first, then P3, while preserving P1/P2 and minimum DCA.

5.3 Sortie Flow per 6-Hour Period (Representative Daily Flow)
The following depicts a representative Phase 2 day (Days 4–7). Phase 1 shifts more weight to 0000Z–0600Z and 1200Z–1800Z for opening/holding; Phase 3 increases “flex” in 1200Z–2400Z for dynamic targeting.

0000Z–0600Z (Primary Strike Window / High-Confidence PNT):
- P1 “Hold/Breach” packages: 10–12 fighter sorties
- P2 node degradation packages: 6–8 fighter sorties + 1 ISR
- P5 HVAA escort + BARCAP: 10–12 fighter sorties
- Enablers: 1 AWACS + 3–4 tankers

0600Z–1200Z (Transition / Degraded PNT):
- P3 sweep / maritime presence: 10–12 fighter sorties
- P5 BARCAP sustainment: 8–10 fighter sorties
- P4 limited interdiction (only if ISR-cued): 4–6 fighter sorties
- Enablers: 1 AWACS + 3 tankers

1200Z–1800Z (Secondary Strike Window / High-Confidence PNT):
- P3 maritime strike / OCA: 10–14 fighter sorties
- P4 deliberate interdiction: 6–8 fighter sorties
- P2 follow-up / re-attack: 6–8 fighter sorties + 1 ISR
- Enablers: 1 AWACS + 4 tankers

1800Z–2400Z (Dynamic Window / Recovery):
- P1 re-attack (as cued): 4–6 fighter sorties (Phase 2) / 2–4 (Phase 3)
- P4 armed recce / SCAR: 6–8 fighter sorties (Phase 3 emphasis)
- P5 night BARCAP and alert launches: 6–8 fighter sorties
- Enablers: 1 AWACS + 2–3 tankers + CSAR alert posture

5.4 AWACS Coverage Rotation (Notional)
Objective: sustain two overlapping orbits in Phase 1–2, then one continuous plus one surge orbit in Phase 3.

a. Orbit structure:
- ORBIT SKYLOOK-1 (forward battle management, corridor control, CAP management)
- ORBIT SKYLOOK-2 (rear/mid, recovery control, tanker management, comm relay)
b. AWACS sorties/day:
- Phase 1: 4 sorties/day (2 per orbit, ~6 hours on-station each with overlap)
- Phase 2: 4 sorties/day (same, with increased comm relay function)
- Phase 3: 3–4 sorties/day (one continuous orbit; second orbit surged during TST windows or adversary raid injects)
c. Emissions and survivability:
- Use minimum required emissions; rely on mission-type orders and procedural control if datalinks are degraded.
- If threat to HVAA increases (exercise inject), pull SKYLOOK-1 aft and increase fighter escort rather than cancel the orbit.

----------------------------------------------------------------------
6. ASSESSMENT CRITERIA (MEASURES OF EFFECTIVENESS)
----------------------------------------------------------------------

Assessment will be conducted daily by the AOC Strategy Division and ISR/Targeting Effects Team using exercise adjudication, simulated BDA, comm logs, and mission reports. MOEs below drive next-day MAAP adjustments and ATO apportionment.

P1 (Destroy A2/AD strike complexes / IADS “gates”)
MOE-P1.1: Percent reduction in modeled threat coverage along Corridors A/B (goal: ≥60% by end of Day 3; ≥75% by end of Day 7).
MOE-P1.2: Number of adversary long-range strike “salvos” disrupted or delayed (goal: disrupt/delay ≥2 major events in Phase 1; ≥1/day thereafter as injected).
MOE-P1.3: SEAD/DEAD effectiveness rate (simulated): ≥70% of tasked emitters suppressed during strike windows.
MOE-P1.4: Blue loss exchange ratio in contested corridor operations (goal: maintain favorable modeled ratio; trigger review if losses exceed “MODERATE” threshold).

P2 (Degrade theater ISR/C2 / targeting network)
MOE-P2.1: Increase in adversary kill-chain timeline (goal: +50% by Day 7; +75% by Day 10).
MOE-P2.2: Reduction in adversary track quality/continuity (goal: persistent “gaps” sufficient to force adversary to rely on less-accurate targeting during ≥2 daily periods).
MOE-P2.3: Friendly C2 continuity under SATCOM loss: ATO execution success rate ≥85% despite comm degradation; critical retasks delivered within planned windows when required.
MOE-P2.4: ISR-to-attack cycle time for preplanned targets (goal: validated/updated target status available within 12 hours for re-attack decisions).

P3 (Neutralize adversary air/maritime strike capacity)
MOE-P3.1: Reduction in adversary sortie generation capacity (modeled) (goal: ≥40% by Day 7; ≥55% by Day 15).
MOE-P3.2: Maritime strike suppression: number of simulated hostile maritime strike attempts prevented or blunted (goal: ≥1 significant disruption per 48 hours during Phase 2–3).
MOE-P3.3: Air superiority indicators: maintain DCA intercept success rate ≥80% during raid injects; limit adversary “leakers” to low single digits as adjudicated.

P4 (Disrupt operational logistics / sustainment)
MOE-P4.1: Modeled fuel and munitions throughput reduction (goal: ≥25% by Day 7; ≥40% by Day 15).
MOE-P4.2: Induced operational pauses or reroutes (goal: ≥1 significant pause/reroute event every 72 hours beginning Day 4).
MOE-P4.3: Re-attack efficiency: ≥60% of re-attacks allocated only after ISR confirmation of continued target value (avoid “wasted” sorties in contested ISR).

P5 (Defend / preserve force and access)
MOE-P5.1: Defended asset integrity: maintain ≥95% DA availability (modeled), with rapid recovery from attack injects.
MOE-P5.2: HVAA survival and mission continuity: tankers/AWACS/ISR complete ≥90% of planned on-station time.
MOE-P5.3: CSAR posture effectiveness (exercise): alert response timelines met ≥90% (scramble-to-airborne, ingress readiness, comm plan execution).
MOE-P5.4: Sortie generation resilience: maintain fighter MC rate and SGR within 10% of plan despite contested logistics/cyber injects.

----------------------------------------------------------------------
MAAP EXECUTION NOTES (FOR DAILY ATO DEVELOPMENT)
----------------------------------------------------------------------

A. Apportionment “Floor” (do not drop below without JFACC approval):
- P1 + P2 combined: minimum 30 fighter sorties/day during Phases 1–2; minimum 24/day during Phase 3.
- P5 DCA/HVAA: minimum 18 fighter sorties/day all phases (CAP + escort combined), surge-capable on 2-hour notice.

B. Apportionment “Flex” (first to trade when constrained):
- P4 is the primary give-back during tanker shortages or PNT degradation.
- P3 is second give-back unless adversary raid injects indicate increased maritime/air threat.

C. Daily Timing Anchors (planning anchors; adjust per weather/EXCON):
- Major strike windows: 0300Z–0700Z and 1500Z–1900Z.
- Dynamic/TST window: 1800Z–2400Z (Phase 3 emphasis).
- DCA CAP changeovers planned every 3–4 hours with tanker support.

D. Degraded Comms Branch Plan (execute when SATCOM/datalink is denied):
- Packages proceed per prebriefed decision points with “continue/abort” triggers tied to threat and fuel.
- Abort criteria emphasize force preservation and recovery to alternate fields/sites (exercise-designated) without requiring real-time clearance beyond procedural control.
